title: WiFi Connections Dropping

thread.text:
I have a Galaxy S6 Active from AT&T and it has worked flawlessly until about a week ago. I've had the 5.1.1 firmware installed well before this issue started. I don't know if an app is conflicting with something or what.
My phone will say I'm connected to WiFi and it'll be fine for a little while. Then apps on my phone will tell me I don't have an internet connection. I turn off the WiFi and then back on and the network is gone (along with everyone else's in the neighborhood that I can usually see). This isn't just at home. It's also at work. When I restart the phone, the network will be back and I can connect again. But then it eventually goes back to not having an internet connection.
I have a 2.4GHz network at home and a 5GHz network. I should not that I am always able to see and connect to the 5GHz network. But even when connected to the 5GHz network, internet speeds are still really slow. I should note that, at home, my 5GHz network is always visible and I'm always able to connect to it.
My internet speed is 10M and both my router and laptop show this when doing a speed test. When doing a speed test on my phone, it's at about .5M or less. I have tried two different routers at home (a Netgear and a Linksys) and my phone is acting the same way with both of them. My work uses 2.4GHz for the WiFi and my phone acts the same way as if I were at home.
I do not have my SSIDs hidden and I'm using WPA2 authentication. I do not have any filtering of MAC addresses. I don't have any special routes configured. The only thing I do have is IP addresses assigned to each device via DHCP. Either way, I've had this setup for years with no issues and now out of nowhere my phone is having issues.
Anyone else having this problem? I'm sure it's something with the phone like an app. I just hope I'm not the only one and that someone might have an idea for me.

replies.text: Yes my s6 active has the same problem with Wi-Fi but also my alarm clock will go off and I get drop calls also when talking on the phone like call waiting goes off I have to send mine back in to Samsung and get a new one

thread.text: Have you installed or updated any apps prior to the WiFi problem? Also, have you checked your data usage? In the data usage you can see both mobile and WiFi usage. Do you have the smart network switch turned on?

replies.text: I've updated quite a few apps. Nothing in the data usage is out of the ordinary. Smart Network Switch is off.

thread.text:
I would look at the recent apps. Check the most recent reviews in the Play Store to see if anyone else is having problems with recent updates. Also, restrict the background data on apps that don't need it.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: That's what I was afraid of. I'm busy enough as it is and was hoping someone else already figured it out. Oh well, I'll have to start looking at the apps. I really don't want to wipe everything and go back to factory.

thread.text: If I turn on my wifi radio, it connects for two seconds, drops, reconnects for 2 seconds and repeats this incessantly. I had some success logging into the router, resetting MAC rules, and then rebooting. That lasts a day maybe and then the drill resumes. I have just turned the wifi radio off except for a one minute period in the morning for any updates. With wifi off my battery life jumps to four days. I have a boomingly strong wifi signal throughout the dwelling. I suspect the issue is on the the router side but every other system in my domain (10-20 devices) work perfectly. During the first month or so that I had the Active, this did not happen. I am still on 5.0.2.

Yes, everything else at home is working flawlessly. There is a location at my work that has 2.4GHz and 5GHz networks. My phone acts the same as if it were at home. The 2.4GHz networks disappear, but the 5GHz network remains.

Your experience seems to indict the phone rather than the router since the problem migrates with you. There is an app called Wifi Analyzer which had an embedded setting called Auto Wi-Fi On. I toggled it on thinking this meant that if the app started and the radio was not on, then the app would start the radio as a convenience. However, with the toggle on, then the radio stays on. At least for the last half hour which exceeds 2 seconds. Why is this? No idea. I am inclined to chalk it up to coincidence to be honest.

Well after doing some searching, I may have found the culprit. The Fitbit app has been giving many users issues with syncing their Fitbit device with the app. The app requires a Bluetooth connection to the bracelet and an internet connection to sync all of the progress with the Fitbit server. I removed the Fitbit and restarted my phone. So far, everything is working good. This sucks though since I use the Fitbit all all of the time. I'll keep monitoring things and keep everyone updated.
Glad you were able to find a possible solution. Hopefully they update the app or have a fix for it.

Hmm. I installed the Android Fitbit app about the time this began. Fitbit caused no problems under Windows 10 which is sufficiently convenient for me. I will uninstall and see what results.
EDIT: No joy in Mudville. Uninstalling did not improve things here.

replies.text: Check out the reviews. It's causing a ton of sync issues.

title: S6 Active, Screen went black flashes blue in left bottom corner. Any help?

thread.text:
I left my galaxy s6 active in the work truck all day while I was working. 
When I got off I went to call my wife and the screen wouldn't come on. Its black blinking blue on the left bottom corner when you hit any buttons. It has not been dropped or gotten wet and has been in an Otter Box. I have tried volume up+volume down+home+power and also tried volume down+power...still nothing. The screen responds..I can still answer calls because I know where the answer button pops up on the screen to swipe it. PLEASE help i just bought the phone.

replies.text: Any luck? The heat inside the car probably damaged the hardware if I had to guess

thread.text: hi, First try Hard reset if it does not solve your problem , then it maybe a hardware problem , If your Phone is in warranty . You should contact them

replies.text: The screen is black I can't see to do a hard reset. It's not under warranty.
Hold the power button and volume down button together for about 10 seconds, this will reboot (hard reset) your phone. You don't need to be able to see anything to have this happen.

title: Trying to transfer old photos to my laptop

thread.text:
Hello all,
Last summer I switched from an iPhone 5c to a Galaxy s6 Active. All my iPhone pix were ported into my new device. The thing is, they're taking up a ridiculous amount of storage space, so I'm trying to transfer them into my laptop. When I connect the phone to the computer, I can't find them! They show up in my gallery on the phone, but I can't see them when the device is connected to the laptop, and searching for them by name didn't help. 
What further information do you need? My phone carrier is AT&T and my laptop is a Dell that is running Windows 10. Any advice would be helpful. Thanks in advance.
Gallery is an app, it doesn't have a "place". IOW, any picture on the phone will show up in Gallery.) Find where the pictures are and copy them.

The problem is just that: I can't find where they are. I've checked every folder that shows up when the phone is connected to the laptop. I've looked in each folder as well as run a search for files named "IMG_". So how can I find them? They are not in the DCIM folder.
Look for a file named SD card backup, or something similar. There is no SD card, but a file. I believe that's where the photos are stored. I don't have my phone in my hand right now.

Samsung Smart Switch™: Transfer Contacts, Music & More
Download the PC version and off you go.
Thanks for the tip, but no such luck. I'm looking through the file folders via my laptop with the phone connected via USB. Am I missing something?

Hi Droid from VA,
Thanks for the tip, but the files are already on my Samsung device; I'm trying to get them off without losing them. I no longer have the iPhone from which they were transferred. I'm trying to find their location do I can move them.
Use "view details" while viewing one of these images in Gallery to see the file path.
Thank you all! I got it! Files transferred!

For future reference for you or others, the LEEF Access MicroSD Card Reader is phenomenal. Great travel companion. Just used it to download 12 GB of photos from my wife's S6 Active (formerly mine) to make room for the Marshmallow update. https://www.amazon.com/LEEF-Access-M...cUvbUpU5258018

title: Why doesn't my Google search widget coordinate with "chrome" or "Internet" on my Galaxy S6 Active?

thread.text:
I use the Google search widget a lot. Often I go do other things on my phone but would like to come back and view the pages I used with the widget. However they cannot be located in either the "Chrome" or "Internet" app. The only way I can find those web pages again is by clicking on the bottom left button on the phone and going through all my opened applications.
Is there a way to make the Google search widget coordinate with either the "Chrome" or "Internet" tabs on my phone?

replies.text:
I hate this too! I hope someone answers your question with an automated solution, but in the interim, it can be done manually from the widget -
From a webpage opened via widget, click the overflow menu in the top-right (the vertical ellipse), then Open in Chrome. This will launch the page in a new Chrome tab and also close the widget.

thread.text: Good question! I hate that too and because of it hardly ever use the widget
I am surprised no one has been able to answer this yet, and I avoid the widget too. Having to open a browser every time for a simple web search is annoying though.

replies.text: Agreed!

thread.text:
I just played around and figured it out! At least on my Galaxy s6 edge...
Go to the device's settings, then under Personal, open Google. Scroll down to Search & Now, then Accounts & privacy, and turn off "Open web pages in app."
I had to restart for the change to take effect, but it worked! Now when I open a webpage from the widget, it opens as a new tab in Chrome.
Thanks

title: Galaxy S6 active scrren is black, phone is locked, computer can't access files

thread.text:
So I am almost ready to give up with fixing my black screen problem but I really want to get my pictures off of my phone. I will never buy a phone again that doesn't have a micro SD slot. since my screen is black ( resets are not working) I can't unlock the phone. When I plug it into my computer, it can't see the files on the phone until it is unlocked. That means my pictures are locked on the phone. Any suggestions on how I can circumnavigate this block? 
Thanks for any ideas.

Try this method: http://forums.androidcentral.com/gen...ed-screen.html
Also, you don't really need an SD card if you turn on Google Photos Auto Backup: https://support.google.com/photos/an...DAndroid&hl=en. The photos are much safer in the cloud than on an SD card, because SD cards fail, too.

Unfortunately there's a reason secure lockscreens are called that: they're secure. Unless you unlock the phone, you can't access its contents. If the phone still has connectivity, you can try to unlock it either from the Google Play Device Manager (using the same Google account on the phone) or, if set up, the Samsung account via Samsung's FindMyMobile. 
If you have connected it before, using SideSync on your computer should display the screen on your desktop, allowing you to unlock the screen using your PC's keyboard/mouse. 
A last resort is using an HDMI cable (via MHL) to watch the screen on a TV IF the screen is still responsive to touch, but I'm not sure if the S6 was still MHL-compatible or not. 
I really hope you can get access to your photos and retrieve them. For next time, however, may I suggest using a cloud back up? There are many out there that are free and most will keep your pictures/videos safe with little to no compression, so SD card or not (SD Cards are highly unreliable, as Alex Dobie can attest to) you still have your pictures safe no matter what, and what's more, available anywhere and on any device. Five things I learned traveling with the Galaxy S7 edge | Android Central

Unfortunately my lock is a swipe pattern lock and not numbers so that first article that B. Diddy pointed me to didn't work. There were a number of people that had teh same issue as me commenting there asking if there was a way to use a similar method with a swipe pattern but no one was able to answer that question.
From the android device amnager it seems that you can lock your phone, but not unlock. Unfortunately I have never used sidesync before (but thanks for letting me know about it, I will in the future) so I think I am SOL. There is no way for me to get teh pin or scan the QR code to initiate the connection. Frustrating. 
I'll take both of your cloud storage suggestions into consideration. Thank you.
Did you try contacting Samsung tech support yet?

Didn't the swipe pattern ask you for a back up password? I'm not sure if it's just fingerprint that does this, but anyway, using SideSync you can use the mouse to emulate your finger on your PC to unlock a swipe pattern. If you could see the screen, you could also use a wired mouse connected directly to the phone via an OTG adapter, but I guess that's not the case here since you say your screen is black (unless you know the motion accurately and emulate it with the mouse without seeing the screen). 
Try using SideSync anyway... I don't remember it asking you for a PIN or QR Code. Might kick in automatically and let you see the screen on your PC.
Also, if you activated a Samsung account to your phone, go to findmymobile.samsung.com I just checked and you can remotely unlock a device from there.

replies.text: System will ask for PIN backup to pattern lock yes

thread.text: Oh, I thought you could use a USB mouse to try duplicating the swipe pattern.

title: So the Active is "rugged", huh?

thread.text:
So, my 11-month-old S6 Active and I were out Friday, and I felt the vibration of a message coming in. Not wanting it to keep annoying me, I took the phone out of my pocket and went to hit the power button. It slipped from my hands and fell, less than 30", to the pavement, landing perfectly square on its back. Wow, that was lucky. Or, so I thought. My screen is destroyed, cracked from top to bottom!
If that weren't bad enough, I've gotten quotes from two different people, that both say it will be over $240 to fix! Oh, man, I am not a happy camper. After reading through other sites, it appears the screen on our phone isn't as "gorilla" as we thought. Disappointed.

replies.text:
I feel your pain my friend. I too had an incident in which the durability of this device came into question. The damage on mine, was a bit different as my 3 year old bit the corner of the device causing a hairline crack. I didn't even see the crack but i knew it was damaged because the screen no longer turned on. I sent it in to Samsung repair that day and they too quoted me something like $317 to fix it. I flew off the handle (not over the phone) but I couldn't believe how a child could damage a "rugged" device sporting the latest gorilla glass. I made my argument to Samsung level 1 and level 2 support, then to the repair center manager, even consumer relations at a point. 
Sure, LCD damage isn't covered under warranty, but its not like you took a hammer to the device. Daily drops or other accidents happen more often than not. 
My advice is to try to work something out with Samsung Support and the repair center. 
1. Keep your cool at all times
2. Keep notes on when you call and who you talk to, ask for a reference or ticket number 
3. Ask for help on resolving the issue (+$240 isn't an acceptable solution as it is too expensive.)
4. Don't demand anything or to speak to a manager/supervisor. Level 1 and in some cases Level 2 support don't make decisions about cost or replacements but they can put you in touch with the people who do. Speak to them as you would want to be spoken to, no matter how frustrating it gets.
The bottom line is that the S6 Active is advertised as a rugged device capable of keeping up with those who have an active lifestyle. To me this means withstanding exposure to the elements, more bumps, drops, or whatever else that isn't considered abuse. 
Also, make sure you know what their warranty states before you call. I would also point out the fact that Samsung Protection Plus is offered on every other S6, Note, and S7 flagship device, and inquire as to why its not available on the S6 Active. One would think its the toughest device and wouldn't need protection plus, but that's not the case. Suggest maybe you would have purchased protection plus had it been available for your device. Even if you purchase protection plus at $129 and replace the device under that, you're still paying less than the $240+. 
The key is to be persistent and polite while dealing with support on the phone. Samsung and the repair center make pretty good money on protection plans and repairs. They can afford to cut people a deal. You just have to try. Good luck.

Thanks, Law. I've already contacted Samsung via email and they got back to me and told me what to do for a possible service claim. I'm probably going to send it to them, just to let them tell me what they "think" it is going to cost, and go from there.

thread.text: Ouch - that sucks! Yes, glass still breaks and is expensive to replace, but sorry to hear that happened. Are you going to fix it or move on to something else?

title: Change/Pause/Play a song using aux?

thread.text: Hello. This may be a noob question but I have a Samsung Galaxy s6 Active and have recently purchased a 2006 PT Cruiser. The car came with an AUX cord which works great for listening to music. However I was wondering if anyone knew of abeing aux cord on which there was a button to change/pause/play a song whilst you are listening to a song (simular to what you find commin on head phones). I will be using downloaded playlist from Spotify not from the internal player on the phone, if that makes a difference. Thank you.

Welcome to Android Central! I think that's unlikely. It depends on the actual jack, not the cable. If the jack doesn't have the contacts for those remote controls, then it won't matter what you plug in. And I don't think car manufacturers would use those jacks, because there's typically an interface on the stereo itself to allow you to skip or pause tracks.

title: battery life

thread.text:
Just got a update on my at&t samsung galaxy s6 active now battery drops a lot faster. Did any one else get this issue after the small update.
Posted via the Android Central App
I got the update and and nothing has changed with my battery life. Try shutting the phone down completely, not just a restart. Leave it off a few minutes then restart it and see what happens.
Clear the cache partition.

Is anyone on the latest update and getting excellent battery life? I feel that after the 5.1.1 update, I am making it through the day with 14% remaining at night. Before, I was going to sleep with at least 40 - 50% remaining. My usage has not changed much, but I feel that app settings may have something to do with it. WiFi shuts off when phone goes to sleep, location services are on because of fitness tracking, and I run package disabler to disable ATT apps and services.

I turn off location at night after a full charge, 10 - 11 pm. Will have 97% in the morning, 7-8 am. I have found, that leaving location on or [redacted] open will drain the battery to 85-93% in the morning.

Yup. I'm having a problem too. I usually could go 35-40 hours on a charge. The last few days, the phone has been getting very hot and barely lasting 8 hours. 
I've turned the phone COMPLETELY off and left it for 10 minutes. - No change
I booted into recovery mode and wiped the cache partition. - No change
I started removing apps, clearing caches of apps, disabling apps. - No change
All this started after the small update. Really don't want to have to factory reset the phone but with the heat and all, I'm afraid that's the last choice I have.

As a quick update, my phone appears to be back to normal. It's not overheating anymore and battery life is back to around 30 hours per charge. 
Not sure what changed. Maybe an app updated. There seems to be a little lag going to the home screen which also started around the same time as the battery/heat issue. Slight annoyance but not a game changer.
My battery life had gone to hell on a bobsled until I installed the leaked Marshmallow build. (available over at xda-developers) After that, it's better than it ever was.

How did you do that?
Posted via the Android Central App
[HOWTO] Update your Galaxy S6 Active firmware to 6.0.1 Marshmallow
And that includes doze feature?

replies.text: Yes. Doze seems to work great, actually.

thread.text: Process took about 3 hours because first try failed and I had to Odin back a couple of versions, then upgrade in steps. And it'll wipe your phone. Just so you're aware of what you're getting into.

Similar issues here. Had the firmware reflashed by Samsung Kiosk after trying all of the usual clear cache, etc. GeekSquad replaced the phone about 3 days ago and the new handset is better, but still a battery sucker. The old handset was also refusing to fully charge after one or two days unless it was powered off, then back on. It would sit on the fast charger all night and not move.

Battery life is still about normal, just a little lower than I used to see before that upgrade. The worst part is that the phone is now VERY sluggish. Like if you're in an app and you hit the home button, it takes literally 2-3 SECONDS before it goes. Tapping the Google search banner, you can see the finger hit on the banner and then 2 seconds later, it goes to search. 
Again, I've tried the cache wipe and complete power off. I guess I'll just pray the Marshmallow update fixes everything. I've really loved this phone until this all started up.

title: Blue Spots on Galaxy S6 Active screen, getting worse!

thread.text: I woke p this morning to a bunch of purple spots all over the screen and they are getting bigger and darker, please someone help I'm on a trip for two weeks and wont be able to get a replacement.

I am assuming that the purple spots are visible no matter what app or screen you are on? Just to see what's going on, I'd completely power down the device and restart it. If the spots are in the same location or continue to grow, then its probably something physical....like the LCD going bad. Any trauma to the device? Did it experience an unusual amount of pressure or force on the screen? If not, then maybe its just an internal issue that should be covered under warranty.
Unfortunately being 2 weeks away from your home address might not help. Normally, ATT sends out a device the same day for warranty exchanges. I don't know if they ship to a location not on record. You'd have to call them and ask if anything can be done...but first you need to be sure its eligible for an exchange or you'll end up buying another Active.
Good luck

title: Samsung Galaxy touchscreen sometimes bails out on me?

thread.text: my phone is an s6 active. Sometimes, the touchscreen just doesn't respond. Restarting and waiting a bit afterwards fixes the problem, but this happens about twice a day. Its not that big of a problem, but im scared something is wrong with my phone. Is there? Or is this just a common bug?

Welcome to Android Central! It could be an app you installed that's malfunctioning. See if it persists in Safe Mode, which temporarily disables all of your 3rd party apps: https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21007

title: Why is my S6 Active touch screen unrsponsive?

thread.text: All the buttons are functional, I receive notifications and my LED light works fine. However, I cannot use the touch screen at all. I tried restarting it like a gazillion times, and deleted the cache. I dont know if I wanna factory reset yet, since I can't backup my photos cause i cant even unlock my phone.

Welcome to Android Central! The digitizer may have simply failed. Any recent trauma or water exposure? Does it persist in Safe Mode? https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21007
If nothing works, contact Samsung (if still under warranty).

If you have access to one of those "on the go cables" plug a mouse into it and you should be able to use that to navigate around and back up your data etc... Once you are in, trying going into the quick toggles at the top and toggling the screen sensitivity toggle. It's worth a shot. Let us know if this worked.

Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
So I got my Nexus 6P yesterday. I have 2 weeks to decide if I am keeping it. Owning Nexus phones before, it is nice knowing that I will receive Android software updates as soon as Google releases them. I did some non-scientific side by side speed tests. Opening apps cold, it was pretty side by side. There were a few times where the 6P opened an app faster than the Active, but on average apps on the Active opened a little faster. Once more than 3 apps were open, the 6p was faster, not having to re-flow many apps. 
I tried entering directions in Google maps. The Active decided to have a brain fart after I put the address in and it just froze for about 5 seconds before putting the pin on the map. Also once navigating, the 6p had no issues multi-tasking and battery drain was minimal. When navigating on the Active, it was running hot and slowing down other apps. I've noticed this with Google maps on the Active. Waze is a bit better, so I usually use that
Camera app on Active is much better, in particular the video recording is better. I haven't figured out if the 6p even supports 60FPS. It only has options for HD video and 4K. Processing of HDR pictures is slow. It doesn't seem to cut down on how fast you can take pictures, but it does affect the time that you can review the picture. Picture quality if good, video is a bit shaky on the 6p. I also found that the video is slower to focus, especially at short distances. The rest of the 6p app is bare bones.
Screen isn't as bright on the 6p at max Brightness vs the Active. I don't think the auto will do the extra boost in the sun, but yesterday was cloudy so I didn't get to try it. If it does, I'll really miss that feature from the Active.
Its silly, but I already miss the Active key.
Fingerprint reader on the 6p is nice, accurate and quick. I never tried the one on the regular S6, so I can't compare.
Volume on the 6p works well. Always annoyed at the nanny dialog on the Active when I boost it past 75% volume. Especially annoying when connected to my car's bluetooth. I usually shut my phone down every day because of my job. I know the dialog doesn't come up after the first time while the phone is running.
No more dialog boxes that pop up on the lower half of the screen! I don't know why Samsung still uses them, they are so annoying. I am always getting messages about slow speed detected even if the speed is fine. Also messages for when connecting to WiFi, etc. 
Much fewer nanny messages. I never understood why I have to acknowledge a dialog after selecting airplane mode. I know why I selected Airplane mode, you don't need to warn me and make me press ok to activate it. Same goes for shutting down! If I took the time to hold down the power button, then select power off, that should be enough for you to understand I want to shut down. I don't need another dialog warning me that you are shutting on than then having to press a button. Basically 3 buttons presses to shut down on the Active.
Much more free space on the 6p. I think is started with only about 4.5 GB used by the system. The Active was closer to 8GB used out of the box. While I like a number of Samsung's enhancements including the camera app, screen adjustments, options layout, etc, I don't like apps like Uber that I can't uninstall. I would say Samsung's features would be worth about 1GB extra to me.
If there was a phone size/screen size/battery size ratio measurement for phones, the Active hits the sweet spot for me. Especially since it really dosen't need a case. The 6p is a bit too big, but I can probably get used to it.
I miss QC2.0, although the 6p charges fast at home, I don't have a compatible charger for my car (yet). But either way, its more stuff to buy.
Lets see if the Active gets an update in the next couple weeks while I can still return the 6P. It would be nice to compare after the update.

@greetings, thanks for the writeup.
So far my Active has been great after my factory reset after the first month of ownership. I agree with your software hangups with Samsung, but the hardware and form factor are just great with the Active. At the moment, my only hangup is with the RAM management. It has now creeped into my head to a point were I don't want to multitask out of my game or video in fear that the app will need to reload and I will lose progress. Normal day to day apps like Feedly, mail, texting are fine as reloads are quick. But if I'm in my game, I really think twice about responding to email or text until I'm at a good stopping point -- pretty annoying in 2015 for a flagship phone.
How's battery on the 6p?
Did you signup for project Fi? Would you consider switching from AT&T?
Things to consider:
- Now that I've dropped my Active 3-4 times, I'd probably get a case for the 6p since it probably wouldn't do well in a drop. That'll add bulk to an already big phone.
- Marshmallow is nice, but there isn't anything I'm craving in that build (unless it fixes RAM management on the S6 Active)
- I booted my OnePlus One the other day and was just amazed at how awesome the screen is on the Active. If the 6p can't compete, you may be regretting the switch.
- Will it be a switch for you? will you be selling the s6 Active? If not, you could always just switch back and forth depending on how you feel that day.
- Battery/charging/wireless charging is important to me, I have invested in QC2.0 accessories and wireless charging pads. It would be hard for me to switch that all out as I have tons of stuff besides my phone that charges using the standard USB cables. You'd have to repurchase spare USB-C cables and chargers.
Anyway, I'm still pretty satisfied with the S6 Active. But that's Android for you, there will be a new flagship released every 3-4 months to get you itching to switch.

@thetruthkc
Haven't run the 6p long enough to say that the battery life is good, but I'll let you know. It seemed acceptable yesterday. Nice thing is I tried streaming audio in my car from TuneIn radio, ran navigation on Google maps, and kept the screen on. Despite all that, the charge went up while I had it plugged into a 2.1 Amp USB car charger. The Active would go down while running all that unless I had it plugged into a QC2.0 port. I found the Active usually has good battery life, but there are times where it uses way more battery than it should. I don't expect the 6p will do that. Marshmallow requires apps to report more battery usage info. Plus since it started with very no bloat so I don't have to worry about apps have no control over. Granted I miss a few of those apps (camera).
I hear there are some thin cases for the 6P, i'm gonna chance it though. I got the Nexus protect plan, so if I beat it up enough I can exchange it.
Marshmallow is nice so far. Yea, nothing stunningly different, but with Doze, better memory and battery management, it should run a lot better over time. 
6P screen is AMOLED, just not as bright as the Active. Only really noticed it when I had them side by side. Both were way better than my girlfriend's Iphone 6+ 
Not sure about selling the Active. I might while it still gets good value (pre S7). Although I might just give it to a family member that needs a new phone. Being able to switch also sounds good. SIM size is the same, so switching would be easy.
Yea a bit annoying with no QC2.0 or wireless charging. I don't always use wireless charging since it is slow, but I do use it from time to time. New cables are annoying too. I do like how positive a click the USB-C connector makes with the phone. Much more secure that before.
The 3-4 month flagship is a bit too much, although no more 810 phones please, next round of flagships should be the 820. Main reason I think about switching back to Apple is getting out of the Android flagship cycle. I actually might switch back with the iPhone 7. It is just nice to only have to get excited once a year . Although at this point the only Android phones I track are the Nexus line and Samsung flagships. Seriously if Samsung could just get off the carrier lock-in boat and start selling direct, I would be very happy. Also they need to work on their memory management. Great hardware, but stupid software decisions are holding me back from being squarely in Samsung's camp. How great would it be if they sold an Active that was unlocked and worked on all carriers? I still see carriers continuing to "distinguish" themselves by locking in the more rugged variant exclusives. Its a shame, because everyone should have access to more durable phones if they want them. Now that carrier contracts are basically dead, carrier locked phones should die too. It probably won't happen quickly enough, especially with Samsung.

I have read somewhere online that samsung has confirmed that the S6 Active will likely receive the update probably in Q1 next year as it is in the "testinf" phase now. I believe Samsung has to work with and improve upon the TouchWiz interface before they put it out. 
I don't plan on getting rid of the Active because it is a wonderful phone with a great camera, battery life, display and so on and I think with the 6.0 marshmellow update in the future, the S6 active will probably be one of the best phones out there.
I doubt we'll be receiving marshmallow. Thank God I'm on the Next 12 program.

title: No Video, Sound only in all Video Players

thread.text:
For some reason, I cannot play any videos that are stored on my device any more, not even the ones I record myself with the device's camera.
VLC player also doesn't play the video, all I get is Audio and a black screen with a monitor icon on it. See link for screenshot.

I've got a serious problem: Regardless what app I use to play a video (even VLC) , (even the videosI recorded myself with my phone), the video doesn't show any picture, instead i only hear sound and the screen goes black and shows this weird monitor icon (See attached).
I've tried clearing cache, rebooting, and about everything else I've read that people suggest. I've only seen 1 person so far with the same problem I have. Anyone know what to do, and how to resolve this?
Thanks.

Welcome to Android Central! Merged threads. It looks like it's trying to cast the screen to a TV or external monitor. Do you have any kind of screen casting/mirroring option turned on, or a 3rd party app that does so?
No, I do not. I have never installed anything that would mirror my phone to an external device or monitor.
Does this happen in Safe Mode as well?
Yes, this also happens in Safe Mode.

That suggests a problem with either the firmware or hardware. You could try reinstalling the firmware, either using Samsung Smart Switch, or manually using Odin: http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...interface.html

Well, here is the funny part: I've tried the stock video player, VLC video player, and many more, and all of them show no picture, just play sound on videos.
But then I downloaded BSPlayerFree, and for some reason this player plays my videos perfectly with picture and sound. So I am not sure what the problem would be on the firmware or hardware side, since obviously videos can be played (just by another app).
Any ideas?

Same problem here, i can't play any of my videos with VLC or phone player, i only get that black screen and the audio of the video..
It's like we're "casting" but there isn't any option to do it, so, nope... 
i only can play my videos normally with the apk 'Google photos'

I could not find a solution to this problem, anywhere, at all.
The next best thing I came up with is to install this Video Player:https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...oid.free&hl=en
And set it as default to play Videos. 
This lets you play videos with sound and picture. 
Let me know if you come across a real fix for it though, I'd still be interested what actually causes our problem.
Otto

Hey, i found something here, i think the problem started with one app i installed which draw on top of the interface of one game, and that probably caused interference with the "output" of the video screen lol
I deleted cache and data of that app and videos works fine for me now. I tried using that app again and the problem came back, so that was my problem.
This is the permission who allows the app to draw on top
Try deleting the cache and data of every app which have that thing 
And restart your device

title: Why can I see the contact file but can't find the contacts?

thread.text: My daughter dropped her S6 active. Screen is unreadable, but phone still works. I am trying to download the contact file to my computer. I can see all the files in the phone, but can't find the contacts. Thanks for your help.

The contacts are in a database file in the phone and, if she entered them all as Google contacts, they're at Google Contacts, so they're safe. (Any phone set up on that account will sync those contacts.)

Also, when you transfer your phone info using Samsung smart switch, AT&T mobile transfer, or if you set up your accounts on the old phone, such as, google, AT&T address Book, Samsung Account, when you set up the accounts on the new phone, the info will be transferred.

title: I want a good qi charger. using otterbox defender

thread.text:
I'm trying to find a good qi charger for my phone. I've heard most qi chargers won't work with this phone and my otterbox defender. Does anyone have any suggestions? I'd greatly appreciate any input. Never used qi charger before. Thanks in advance!
Posted via the Android Central App

So I have three Qi chargers, two from Nokia, one from Samsung. They all work just fine. Your problem is that the Otterbox case may be too thick to get a signal to charge (or whatever magic makes it work). Try going to an ATT store and testing it out. they usually have a few chargers on display.

For what it's worth, I have an Otterbox Symmetry cover on our S5 with wireless back installed. It charges wireless just fine. I have an Incipio DualPro on my S6 Active and it does wireless charging without any issues. Using a Samsung wireless charger. 
Samsung now has a wireless quick charger as well.

I have tested both the Anker and Samsung wireless chargers with my Otterbox Defender case. Both work, but the alignment of the wireless antenna on the phone has to be lined up with the charging pad antenna or the charging doesn't happen. 9/10 times, that's what goes wrong when people try to use a charging pad and it doesn't help that many of the pads are now using compact designs while the phones are significantly larger. It's my understanding that the older pad designs were larger than the phones or about the same size, so they were easier to work with. I myself bought a bunch of Anker pads in addition to a single Samsung one and I gave up on using them because it's simply easier, faster, and more efficient to just use USB charging because it JUST WORKS. Put your phone on a charging pad and the connection might be good, but if someone bumps your phone even half an inch or a few centimeters, it goes off the charging path and you're no longer charging your phone.

What DroidFromVA said. I've been using the LuguLake pad with the Defender case on a Note 3 since before forever, and it works fine. ANY Qi charge situation needs to have the phone lined up properly - with or without a case - it's just not as critical without the case.

I have the Samsung wireless charger. I have the Defender case on my GS6A and it charges just fine. As others have said, you have to have the phone positioned correctly on the charging pad - but, once you see how the phone has to sit on the base to get the wireless charge, it quickly becomes habit sitting your phone down in the appropriate position/angle. Taking the time to physically plug your phone becomes more time consuming once you get used to things.
I use the RavPower wireless charger. Not only does it charge my phone wireless but it has a built in 5000 mah battery so you can use it as a power bank as well.

title: Dose Samsung S6 Active support OTG?

thread.text: Dose the Samsung S6 support on the go function
I've plugged in OTG cable to use usb keyboard. Works OK

If you attempt to use a USB OTG drive with the phone as you would an average phone or tablet, you will find that the microUSB plug is too short to properly connect with the phone's port and that the body of the OTG drive bumps against the case of the phone due to the port being recessed and covered, which only allows USB connectors that use the standardized cable dimensions - which fit perfectly inside the recessed area where the port sits - to be used with the phone. If you want to use a USB OTG drive, you will have to get an adapter cable that takes USB female and converts it to microUSB male. StarTech has such an offering and you can get it from Amazon for a pittance.
I use mine with the following OTG drive and it works flawlessly:http://www.amazon.com/SanDisk-connec...cUvbUpU5091038

title: How can I add music to my Samsung S6 Active? What is the best app to use?

thread.text: What is the best and easiest app to use?

replies.text: I actually don't use an app. I use YouTube and a YouTube converter. Go to google and type "youtube converter" and click the first one. Go to YouTube or the YouTube app, find the video of the song you want, and tap "share" and then copy the link. Copying can be done by long pressing the word or in this case the link. In the YouTube app there is an option to copy it. To paste you also long press but press the paste icon instead of the copy icon. Delete the text in the box on the converter website and paste the link there. Then hit convert and once it converts (usually around 5-15 seconds but can take up to a few minutes based on Internet speed) hit download. Find it under recent in the music app that comes already on your phone.

thread.text:
Welcome to Android Central! Are you interested in purchasing music for download, or subscribing to a streaming service?
Be aware that "free MP3 downloaders" are often of questionable integrity and legality, and may increase your risk for malware.

You might want to check out this article. The best music player apps for Android http://www.androidcentral.com/best-m...layers-android
If you want to upload songs from your personal music collection to Google Play Music, please see the following link. https://support.google.com/googlepla.../1075570?hl=en

I usually just copy files from my PC to my phone if I have music I want to put on the phone (assuming it's not single-copy-use licensed). For example, I have a copy of the full performance of "Thus Spake Zarathustra" (the theme of 2001: A Space Odyssey) on my phone because I love the piece. Just copied a Creative Commons licensed recording to the phone - simple. (I have a folder on my SD card named mp3 for music.)
If you have a particular folder/file organization on your PC (like artist/album/tracks here), copy the whole top folder and you'll keep the organization. (I prefer doing it manually, rather than the Music Manager link Laura gave, because then I'm certain what's going where, and I can skip or add anything I like. Then again, it took 3 years to drag me from DOS to Windows.)

title: S6 Active texting with pics?

thread.text: I have a new S6 active, I know how to use a smart phone but this is the first I've owned... when I text with a pic. it sends in 2 separate messages. Is that "normal" or is there a way to send them together in one text?

Welcome to Android Central! If you select a photo to send first, I think it sends the photo without letting you add text. Then you have to follow up with a text. If you type the text first, then attach the photo, it might send as a single message, but I'm not sure.
It was something that started happening with the 5.1.1 update. But B Diddy is right, if you put the text in first then add the photo it will be sent as one message.

If you go to Settings>Data Usage>Mobile Data> and uncheck Enhanced LTE services it will turn this function off and will allow your pictures to send with any text you type. This will also make it so you can't use video chat and you will lose some other enhanced LTE functions.

replies.text: Did you root your old s6? Rooting definitely helps extending battery life in some way. Unfortunately, I don't think we would have root for the active. I had my s6 with root. I would say the active can take 15 % more usage compare to rooted s6, and 25% more than non-root s6.

thread.text: The S6 Active battery life is amazing in my opinion. I use my phone for personal use, as well as business, and I can easily get through a day under heavy usage. A normal day is about 16hrs of usage, and I'm usually at around 40% when I plug it up at night. I was originally going to go with the S6, but after reading reviews on the Active, I changed my mind and I'm glad I did.

replies.text: Wow I used to get just 4 hours in beast mode on my S6 .This makes it tempting for me .

thread.text: I concur, my battery life is amazing as well. I'm a light user and can make it 2 days on one charge. I bought the Active because I wanted an S6 but also wanted great battery life and the option to use without case and worry about drops etc. The Active is the best phone I have owned to date.

I'm running an S6 Active with the latest updates and Samsung Pay installed. Battery life is not that great unless I disable the Location service, which then makes the battery life excellent, as the current build has Location pings every few seconds and there's no way to change the default setting to alleviate that. Also, Samsung Pay runs a bit slow and lags. It often takes several seconds (5-8) to bring up the PIN input.

Even with heavy usage, I get over a day's worth on this phone. Of course, I'm not streaming a ton of Hulu/Netflix or anything, so if that's what you do, I couldn't tell ya. But surfing, texting, calls, etc. I get really good battery life from this phone.

I'm like rong above - a very light user - Location Service off unless needed, not streaming a lot, low brightness with a quick "sleep" setting (1 minute of inactivity). 
I got my S6A on Wednesday Dec. 23, 97% charged out of box. Did the whole setup, upload Apps from Google Play, etc... and with my usage, finally dropped to 19% today (Saturday Dec. 26) - that includes leaving the phone on overnights as well... for me, the battery is amazing.

As a guy who's always on social media (twitter, snapchat, etc), playing high graphic games such as Vain Glory or Asphalt 8, and playing music from youtube, Spotify and other services, I still end up with about 14-16 hours of use throughout the day. Much better than the iPhone I had before this, better than my brother's regular s6.

The battery life in my 6 month old Active has taken a recent plunge to 12 hours a day battery life. Not sure why. Anyone else experience this? I use a pebble time, BTW. Thx for your reply

MAL LIGNANT:
How does your Samsung Galaxy S6 Active use the Facebook **APP** when the developer page for the app says that it is NOT COMPATIBLE with the Samsung Galaxy S6 Active? 
Perhaps you are using an older version of the app and you have not updated to the new version. 
For those of us that DID install the updated version of the Facebook APP on November 10-11, 2015, we STILL cannot access the app functions. 
Like the OP, I also uninstalled the app because of many issues with the Comments and updating my Feed. I attempted to reinstall the app from Google Play Store but was stopped by a message from Facebook Developers that their app was "not compatible with your (my) device." 
Does anyone KNOW any **productive** information about this situation? (By productive, I mean that I do not need to know if the app works on your phone!) There are several thousand of us that are having this issue with our Galaxy S6 Active phones. When will it be resolved, Samsung?
It is probably a SAMSUNG GALAXY S6 ACTIVE issue--not a Facebook APP problem. But, who fricken knows, at this point!
Thank you to those of you that post legitimately helpful information.

title: what protective cases are compatible

thread.text: What protective cases are compatible with the Samsung s6 active

Welcome to Android Central! Do a search for "S6 Active case." You need a case designed specifically for the Active, because it is not the same size as the S6, and button and port placements are also somewhat different.

There is another thread out there for this, so you'll find a lot of options there. 
I personally recommend the Tudia case. It's affordable, fits great, and holds up fantastically.
I use an Otterbox case. Works perfectly and it matches the phone.

replies.text: The G3 has a great camera and is quick to focus and snap pictures. I would suggest making sure the lens is clear of any smudges that may affect the focus.

title: Music Player Issues

thread.text:
Hi all,
Wondering if anyone has had similar issues - I've never seen this happen before until I got the G6A...sometimes my music player will turn on automatically, or skip to the previous (or next) song, adjust volume, etc. Sometimes it seems to think I'm trying to use voice commands.
I'm on Android 5.1.1, BOJE build, and using RocketPlayer (with BrainWavz Headphones).
It will start fine, and then all of a sudden, while in my pocket (where I carry the phone) it will self-adjust in one of the above mentioned ways. At first I thought it might be static in the air, but noticed sometimes the same issues occur if I'm holding it in my hand, or if I'm putting it in my pocket and touching the screen (although the screen is off and locked).... 
Thanks for any thoughts!

title: Percentage Drain Discharge when screen is off per hour typical for S6 active?

thread.text:
I've recently just got a new S6 active, coming from windows phone 10 on a Nokia Icon.
On the icon, using Insider Pro, i would see a discharge rate of about 2% per hour when the screen was off, no matter if bluetooth was on or off and other services as well.
Now to the S6 active.. the other day i ran similar tests using GSam battery monitor.
I swear I was also seeing about 2% per hour, at least then i was.. i've been toying with new apps since then, now i cant go below 3% per hour.
So i'm asking.. for a typical screen off period.. what rate per hour is considered Normal for this phone? Also.. waking up, i might be at 99-100%, then after 15 minutes i drop to 96% or lower, easily, just from reading emails.
Also.. gsam is a pretty good app, but are there any others that work well showing both discharge and charge rates?
I'm also wondering if any of these apps that promise to save on battery life are worth trying.. i had tried one, i think it was du battery.. and it had tons of adware and i think made things worse in terms of the phone being sluggish too..
I just discovered JuiceDefender... not sure if its worth trying or not?
EDIT: i must say, i turned it to airplane mode, turned the screen off.. over 59 minutes ZERO percent drain, on the nokia icon this would never happen.. 
Still interested in hearing typical % per hour drains with screen off and without airplane mode though.
Any thoughts?
Thanks in advance

IMO this is a pretty subjective topic because we've all got different apps, preferences and settings on our devices. What I can tell you is that, PRE 5.1.1 update, some of us were getting stellar battery life with little screen off drain. There's been discussion as to what causes this drain, but there's no definitive answer. I for one, am hoping that the Marshmellow update fixes this issue. 
I'm not in a position to test my battery life with airplane mode on for an hour, so I couldn't give you much feedback there. At night, if I forget to plug in, it will usually drop around 10-12% with screen off.

I can unplug my phone before going to sleep and while sitting all night it drops only 1 to 2 percent max with sync on. So after 7 to 8 hours 2% max with sync on. I have all the bloat disabled and don't have any social media apps syncing. I'm running latest update as well; 5.1.1. I have an LG Vista also and it doesn't lose any battery while sitting, 0%. I've got a galaxy S3 and it drops 1 to 2% per hr sitting idle. Ran it the same way as well. They have definitely improved the software since the GS3 days. I can garauntee it's an app causing the drain.
This is from last night:

My last test, lasting 1 hour since screen was off with Gsam is showing 2.2%/hr drain (screen off) with location services off. I've tried various things, but i cant pinpoint where the s6 active is draining most.. biggest ones are always in the Android System (17%) or kernel 15.7%.. if i try turning off wifi, then the phone radio spikes up to compensate. I'm wondering if its related to Aquamail.. i have it syncing a bunch of google mail folders (imap push on may 2 of them out of say 7.. and also the same for exchange.. with interval checks at 30 mins though, so not sure (I do have 6 aquamail widget icons to show notifications and i also run with nova prime + tesla unread badges).. Next step, ill turn off tesla unread and see if i can get below that 2.2 per hour off rate.

For what it's worth, I unplug my Galaxy S6 phone around 6am when I get up and it's down to 20 or 30% by noon. Dead by 4 pm.
My old Samsung Galaxy S3 would still show 50% charge at bed time!
Typically I unplug at 6 am. I listen to a book via blutooth headphones on my 30 minute commute. Once I'm in the office, I'm connected to Wifi and usually leave my blutooth and location ON. Dead by mid afternoon....

replies.text:
Galaxy S6, 2550 mAh. I can see that happening. 
Galaxy S6 Active, 3500 mAh. I don't see that happening. Actually, even with the battery drain issue, I never drop below 20%.

thread.text: I discovered on the s6 active.. (not that surprising i guess), that if i turn ON airplane mode.. 0% for the most part, drop per hour when screen is off.. turn it back on.. i'm typically around 2.2 (at best) to the usual 3.2-3.5% per hour rate when the screen is off and not using it much (using gsam monitor, the option to calculate since screen last on).. on a given 8 hour day with very milld use of the phone throughout the day, the 8 hour average seems to be around 7.5% i believe (per hour).. typical on rate of discharge, just browsing around is about 9% per hour..

I hate to wipe the phone and do things one by one if this drain is typical for this particular phone.
On average i see in GSAM, a discharge rate of about 4.5-5.5 per hour with the screen off.. can anyone else with the s6 active 64gb verify they see the same rate of discharge when the screen is off? (about 0% if on airplane mode) (using the GSAM app).

replies.text:
Ok, gave it a shot, mostly the same.. between 3-4% with the phone basically not on at any point over the course of an hour.
It might have reduced consumption by maybe 0.75 % per hour, but hard to say.
That said.. discharge rates when the phone is turned off (screen)over an hour of 3-4% pretty typical, or worth wiping and trying one by one to figure out which app causes it (vs 0% if on airplane mode). Like i said depending on what you are doing when its on, the rates are anywhere from 8% to 18% depending on if browsing (maybe 8%), spotify with phone off (8%) or gps + spotify on battery (17+ percent), i think to run a game might be somewhere near 14% per hour discharge. I'm guessing all this is just the way it goes, though having that 4% guaranteed drain to offset use makes it drain even faster.

Another stat to pass along.. on the s6 active 64..
If you launch a 3d game.. say the vr cedar point app.. let the phone sit with it running.. 33 minutes goes by and so does 14%.. gsam shows a rate of discharge of roughly 25%.. thats 4 hours of 3d game time.. i'm thinking thats a pretty good discharge rate actually.

title: Why are my text messages freezing?

thread.text: I updated my Samsung Galaxy S6 Active a few days ago and now some of my text message threads are freezing really bad. I deleted a lot of content from my phone in hope that giving it more room to function would help. It has not seemed to. Now, I have to create a "New Message" every time that I want to text a few specific people. Any one have any suggestions? Also, pictures are not sending as well. They will fail about 4 or 5 times before actually sending. S.O.S.

Welcome to Android Central! Are those freezing threads full of thousands of messages? That can bog down the Messaging app's performance.
Are all of the freezing threads group chats? If so, then that, along with the fact that pictures aren't sending well, suggests an isolated MMS problem. Check your APN settings and make sure they're correct.
You can also try wiping the cache partition, which won't erase any personal data: https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21095

title: On my Galaxy S6 Active it constantly pops up a loading ring with please wait beside it. What should I do?

thread.text: I can close out all apps and be sitting on the home screen doing nothing and it will still pop up... it does it on 4G and WiFi. If I'm on an app it will back me out of what I'm doing or if I'm watching a video it will close it out... I can't tell if it's a virus or just something wrong with the phone.
Welcome to Android Central! Does this happen in Safe Mode? https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21007
Is it a spinning circle with an icon of a TV remote control? It might be the Peel app.http://forums.androidcentral.com/sam...-up-today.html
Okay in safe mode been running it for a few minutes now and it hasn't happened yet...
I'm the original post just got my account set up
No its not that it's literally just a spinning circle and "please wait"

If it doesn't happen in Safe Mode, then the problem is probably being caused by a 3rd party app. The challenge now is to figure out which app. You might have to uninstall apps one by one until that behavior goes away.
I don't have any 3rd party apps is the problem... I've got music from sketchy sites though

Avoid "free MP3" download sites or apps. The ones that don't get shut down typically grab the files from other servers (usually filesharing sites), and say in their Terms of Service that it's only meant for "fact-finding," and the files must be deleted off your computer or device after you're done "fact-finding." Keeping them on your device would be considered copyright violation.
And since those sites are grabbing files from outside servers, there's definitely risk for malware embedded in the files.
I'm guessing the only way to fix this is back up my pictures/contacts and format the phone?

You haven't installed any apps outside of the ones that came with the phone? That'd be pretty unusual for most users. If you have installed any other apps, uninstall those first, before considering a factory reset. title: Android Auto Not Working

thread.text:

Posted via the Android Central App
Having the same problem with my active. Android auto will recognize my old nexus 5 easily but not the active.

Any other S6 Active users having problems with Android Auto? I've been having issues with my Kenwood DDX9207S head unit where it sometimes doesn't initialize AA properly, is more often than not very laggy, etc. Sometimes it runs smoothly, as I would expect for a phone of this class with these specs, but it's getting pretty frustrating. I've tried clearing Android Auto's data/cache and uninstalling and reinstalling it, but nothing seems to help. I'm not sure if it's an AA issue, phone issue, or possibly the head unit (very doubtful, but the screen sometimes stays stuck on AA after disconnecting the phone). I can sometimes resolve the issue simply by unplugging and replugging the phone in, sometimes I have to kill all app processes, and sometimes I have to flat out reboot the phone.
EDIT:
Did some testing last night and this morning during my commute (I sit in a lot of traffic, don't worry) and found a possible culprit: Settings. I looked at the memory usage for apps, and without fail, everything was using very little memory except Settings, which was eating 100-300mbs. Killing the process instantly made AA responsive again, but within 5-10 minutes, I was seeing lag again, and Settings was building up memory usage. I'm going to perform a factory reset on the phone today to see if that alleviates the issue.
EDIT II:
After factory resetting the phone, I'm not seeing issues, SO FAR, with AA. The settings thing wasn't the right target. I still get high RAM numbers with it regardless, and I see the same thing on my Tab S2, so that's obviously not what was causing the issue. The difference *might* be that I disabled a lot of AT&T bloatware before, and in doing so might have messed something up. I'm leaving everything enabled right now, so we'll see how this goes. I only have one car ride under my belt so far, so it's not a very scientific comparison.
EDIT III: 
Ran into the exact same issues earlier this afternoon. Plugged the phone in, got the "Accept" screen on my head unit, and then blank. I looked at my phone and realized that AA didn't actually launch, so I unplugged it and plugged it back in. It launched that time, but the lag was there. I can take up to 10 seconds for AA to register a touch, and Maps freezes up constantly for 10 seconds or so before trying to catch up (it usually doesn't catch all the way up before it freezes again). This makes AA more or less unusable for me. I can't find anyone else out there that has had these issues with AA and this phone, so I'm unsure of what the issue actually is. The only difference between last night and today is that last night I was listening to podcasts through Pocket Casts, and today I used Audible. I'll do a bit more testing with/without Audible to see if that's the culprit; I know AA support is relatively new on Audible (though it was in the beta for a while). Again, I haven't seen anyone complain of poor AA performance while using Audible, so I don't know if that's the issue. I wish I had a Nexus to test this against to see if its the phone...

title: Current owners and prospective buyers of this device - Waterproof and IP68

thread.text:
I currently own a Galaxy S6 Active that malfunctioned after being exposed to water (Splash Park for kids with sprinklers). After about 10 minutes at the park while taking some photos, the screen blacked out momentarily and the device reset. About 15 minutes later, a fog and beads of water were visible inside the front facing camera lens. The screen remained non responsive for several hours and improved only after I placed it in a dehumidified basement. The screen functions fine now, however, the physical back button has stopped functioning properly. I have filed a ticket with Samsung customer support.
My hope is that this issue can be resolved and my device can be repaired or replaced to perfect working order. I also hope to shed some light on Samsung's advertisement of this device in terms of meeting IP68 standards and Samsung's warranty coverage.
Samsung.com states:
"Dustproof and water-resistant,† the Galaxy S6 active has a rugged design that’s engineered for outdoor activities. Run in the rain, camp in the desert, dig in your garden—all with your phone by your side."
†This device passed military specification (MIL-STD-810G) testing against a subset of 20 specific environmental conditions, including temperature, dust and sand, shock/vibration, and low pressure/high altitude. Device may not perform as shown in all extreme conditions. Water-resistant and dustproof based on IP68 rating, which tests submersion up to 1.5 meters for up to 30 minutes. 
Ok, Samsung officially states that this device passed military specification (MIL-STD-810G). For water related testing, I did some further research on what this MIL-STD-810G includes. Test Method 512.5 Immersion: This method determines if a device can withstand being submerged or partially submerged in water, or just splashed a lot, and be able to function after or even during the process. This test will determine if a device warrants an IP rating with a second number as high as a 7. There is one procedure applicable to electronic devices:
Procedure I (immersion) covers putting any part of the device underwater. The test starts by weighing the device. Then every panel, door or cover that might be opened during use is opened and closed three times each. To test the affects of a temperature differential on the seals, the device can be warmed up to 10 to 27 degrees C above that of the water. Then the device is placed into the water so that its top side is one meter below the surface for 30 minutes. Partial immersion is used in cases where the device is designed to float, but other than the depth, the test is largely the same.Note that the specification does not cover the highest IP rating for liquids – 8, which involves depths of more than one meter and longer durations, and would have to be verified independently of this MIL-STD.
Since the S6 Active carries an IP68 rating, there should be no doubt that it passes tests for IP67 standards.
My argument here is that Samsung is telling us that the device passed military spec testing, and is water-resistant and dustproof based on IP68 rating.
What does IP68 really mean? In short, IP is referred to as ingress protection or international protecting rating. The first digit is for solids, such as dirt, dust and other particles. The second number is for liquids. So, IP68 means - 6 = dust tight 8 = The equipment is suitable for continuous immersion in water under conditions which shall be specified by the manufacturer. Normally, this will mean that the equipment is hermetically sealed. However, with certain types of equipment, it can mean that water can enter but only in such a manner that it produces no harmful effects.
For the warranty on the S6 Active, Samsung.com states: 
"This Limited Warranty does not cover: (a) defects or damage resulting from accident, misuse, abnormal use, abnormal conditions, improper storage, exposure to liquid, moisture, dampness, sand or dirt, neglect, or unusual physical, electrical or electromechanical stress; (b) scratches, dents and cosmetic damage, unless caused by SAMSUNG; (c) defects or damage resulting from excessive force or use of a metallic object when pressing on a touch screen..."
So Samsung is saying, Our product can do this (endure specified liquid conditions based on IP68), but if it malfunctions within IP68 conditions, it is not covered under our warranty.
I'll be back with an update after contacting Samsung phone support.

replies.text: FYI, I have 3g microcell problems with the s6 active and when I called tech support they said the only "known issue" with the active is the water ingress issue. So getting a replacement is a slam dunk from at&t but, of course, it will be a refurb. OP may already be aware but for others this info may be valuable.

thread.text:
I contacted AT&T support and inquired about my device being covered under the exchange program. I explained that my device malfunctioned after being exposed to water. The support specialist ran some remote diagnostics which revealed the back button is malfunctioning. However, I wanted it to be perfectly clear that I think that this issue is related to water. The specialist processed the warranty exchange, but also stated that if the device is determined to be damaged due to water, that I will be charged for the replacement $616.00. A new device is on the way. She also suggested that I go to a ATT store so they can determine if the device is in fact damaged due to water. I guess there is a physical examination they can do in the sim card tray. 
I know for a fact that water got inside because of the water beads in the lens. Its definitely a Samsung issue, but they drag their feet on support and replacement turn around times. 
I'll get the device checked at my local ATT store and see what they say.

So the associate looked up the indicator location which is in the SIM tray and advised me that the LDI was not tripped. I asked him to show and explain it to me, and it is still white. If water had contacted the strip, it would be purple or pink.
I accept that's all he can do, as he is not qualified to physically open the device for further examination. I know for a fact water was somewhere in the device because of this photo. I want to be 100% sure what is causing this issue and it is properly resolved.

After a few hours on the phone with Samsung Support, I was finally forwarded to Executive Customer Relations. (This took multiple attempts and explanations of the issue to level I phone and chat support.) I will be sending the phone in for further evaluation to determine if the malfunction is due to water or hardware failure. Any way I look at it, the physical buttons, screen, or anything else on the device should not be affected by water conditions that fall within the scope of IP68. The water beads inside the camera lens indicate there is water entering into the device somewhere. This picture of the LDI sticker inside the SIM tray indicate that water did not enter the device through the SIM slot. There is a bad seal somewhere.

I ended up getting my device repaired free of charge.

Power Down the Galaxy S6
Press and Hold the Power Button, Volume Up Button and the Home Buttons at the Same Time
Continue Holding These Buttons Until You See Some Blue Text at the Top
When You See the ‘Recovery Booting….” Text, Then Let Go of These Buttons
Wait Until the Galaxy S6 Fully Boots into the Recovery Mode

title: Contact bdays

thread.text: When I enter a Google account contact into the contact app and enter their birthday it's not carrying over to the standard calendar app. I have the birthday setting on in the settings but still no go. Anyone else having this issue? I've been fighting with it for months

Is your Google account set to sync Calendar and Contact items? If you go to your calendar on the web, do the birthdays show up there? In the Calendar app, make sure that CONTACT BIRTHDAYS is active in the MANAGE CALENDARS (or Calendars to Display, depending on your model) setting.

SpookDroid I want to thank you for your help. The birthdays are now showing on the calendar app. I logged into my Google Gmail and Google Calendar on the web like you suggested. The birthdays all appeared properly on the web version of the calendar. I noticed after logging into my Google Calendar on the web (which I NEVER do, probably my first time doing so in months or possibly years), when I went into the calendar app on my phone and selected "Manage Calendars" a new a field titled "Birthdays" appeared under my Gmail account and was off. I turned it on and boooyaaa, the birthdays now appear in the calendar app. Prior to logging into my Google Gmail and Calendar today on the web, when I opened my calendar app on my phone and entered into my "Manage Calendars", I did not have a "Birthdays" field listed under my Gmail account. I always had a "Contacts' birthdays" listed under the "Device" section in the "Manage Calendars" and that was always "on", so I thought I had everything I needed for the birthdays to appear properly. Apparently, logging into my Google Calendar on the web triggered the new field of "Birthdays" to appear in my "Manage Calendars" under my Gmail account. As strange as that sounds, that is exactly what happened. I am a happy now, as the issue was driving me crazy for the past year or so. Thanks again!

Mmm... that's weird, but good to know that maybe a login to the web version is needed to force certain fields!

title: No way to turn off just Notification Sounds for a given app? way to hide /expand lockscreen content?

thread.text:
Couple of questions i cant seem to figure out..
For the built in email app.. it seems there is only the option of notifications on or off.. there is no option for turn off sound notification, but still show the notification message in the lockscreen?
The other thing i'm wondering, for both sms and emails in the lockscreen.. is there no way to have the content hidden, but only hidden until an arrow is pressed to the right of it to reveal the full mesage.. this is a basic feature of windows phone 10 that seems to be lacking here (in addition to the lacking of calendar items for multiple days visible on the lockscreen).
Thanks in advance

replies.text:
To hide content on lock screen you have to go to SETTINGS> SOUNDS AND NOTIFICATIONS > APP NOTIFICATIONS 
and select the apps that you want to have content blocked on the lock screen. 
For example, I selected "Messages" and then turned ON the "Hide content on lock screen" button. Hope this helps.

thread.text:
1) You can select NONE as a sound in the notification settings of your e-mail or messaging app. 
2) Unfortunately, nope. The only way that will happen is when you have multiple notifications waiting (expand with two fingers swiping down, no 'right arrow'). There might be 3rd party apps that show the notification in a different way, but not the stock apps.

Thanks Phoneguy! I had forgotten about that setting! However, it won't exactly solve what mark is asking. That will effectively hide content on the lockscreen (while showing content for other apps), BUT there's no way to expand the notification on the lockscreen to 'reveal' the message afterwards. You'd have to do it through the notification bar.

replies.text: Yeah, i discovered the option of "silent" for disabling the sound for a given app's notification.. but there is no real way to have the content still show on the lockscreen, but in a collapsed view until an arrow is pressed, unless like you mention there is a 3rd party or rooted way of achieving this (as well as making is so the security area doesnt suck up 3/4 the screen just from turning the phone on to see notifications).
You got it and thank you sir as well.

thread.text: Yup, those are modifications that would have to be made to the core system, which in this case, means custom ROMs.

The GMail app lets you create a widget on the home screen for a particular folder, but tapping it just opens GMail to that folder, you can't read the email on the home screen.

title: Samsung Is The Boss!

thread.text:
Short story:
Got my second s6 Active, cuz my daughter liked mine so much, she suckered it from me! So, I get my company to get me one, as I had been using my personal phones for work anyway, cuz i hate apple, and that's all they originally allowed us to have.
Dropped it from my truck on first day....no issues! Dropped it again on 3rd day, permanently lost touch screen, then lost screen all together.
Contacted my company cell handler, told her what happened and asked her if she wanted me to send it in to Samsung, because the phone should not have broken, and that the screen didn't even crack. She said, in her experience with Samsung, that they'll end up charging us, and said she'd just purchase another and send to me; got it the next day.
Now, I said, what the heck....sent it to Samsung...you guessed it, it was covered, they repaired and sent it back to me. Now, I have a spare, in great working order.! :-D
The phone apparently fell at just the right angle, I guess....because the one my daughter has, has been dropped so many times, its a wonder it still functions.
Great phone, love it....and my spare too! 
Just thought I'd share!
Chris

Wow, I'm surprised Samsung fixed it free! Even though it's an Active, I would have thought they'd still charge you, since the problem was due to trauma, rather than a manufacturer's defect. Glad it worked out for you!

replies.text: Exactly. And I didn't try to soften the landing. I told them I dropped it from about 3 feet out of my truck. It only left 2 very small little nicks, in the left side, near the active key. I went on in my complaint, to describe that this phone was advertised as being rugged, with a samsung promoted video, of it being knocked around a hockey court. I of course ended my complaint with, please help me, I'm a die hard samsung fan, and this is a let down on a product that advertises ruggedness. Well, I guess it worked. (And probably being polite helped too!)
That was absolutely the best approach. They probably made an exception for you based on your reasoning and reasonableness, and not based on any policy they may have.
Yes, perhaps...Kill'em with kindness, that's always my approach! :-D

title: Hey, I just got the Samsung Galaxy S6 Active, and I was wondering how I can get it to text wrap?

thread.text: I want to be able to text wrap in the Internet browser, how do I do that?

Welcome to Android Central! Are you talking about Samsung's stock Internet browser, or Chrome? It's not possible on Chrome, and it probably isn't on the stock Internet browser either. See this article from 2014: [Bug Watch] Text Reflow Removed From WebViews In KitKat, Probably Not Coming Back

Text wrapping depends on how the site page was written. Good sites have separate mobile pages that are written to wrap. Sites "written" by people who don't know what they're doing use a "mobile theme", which messes up the wrapping ability of the page. There's nothing you can do on your end. (Reflowing and wrapping are different. Reflowing corrects for a page that can't wrap.)
That's a good distinction. Perhaps the OP could give us an example of a page that isn't wrapping as desired.

title: new to samsung

thread.text:

1. Buy and use a case on it, despite how "rugged" and tough you may think the device may be.
2. Underwater usage may have varying results. You may experience low or muffled audio for several hours, performance issues with the display, VOIDED Warranty. (Pay no attention to the underwater mode for the camera, I wouldn't recommend taking it into the water)
Enjoy the great camera, display and physical buttons! Despite the issues, I still love this device.
Also checkout Samsung Account as this is far superior to Android Device manager which is no use if location services are turned off
Enable Android Device Manager, create a Samsung Account, disable carrier bloatware or bloatware you don't use.
