title: Samsung Wants Me to Pay for Something that is a Factory Defect?!

thread.text: So my phone's display stopped working out of the blue. I know the phone can still power on because it vibrates when I get a notification, the led indicator light still flashes, I can still connect it to my laptop and copy files, and it vibrates when I hold down the power button to reset it. The screen won't turn on no matter what I do though. I've tried every form of reset that exists, so in the end I sent it in to samsung to hopefully get it repaired. Now I find out they want to charge me for a new LCD. What it says on the ticket is "Out of warranty by condition, LCD is damaged". Keep in mind that I have never dropped this phone, gotten it wet, applied any pressure other than normal tapping with my finger (I never put it in my back pocket so I couldn't have sat on it), it has never been exposed to anything outside of room temperature and optimal conditions. Is there anything I can do in this situation? I have called customer support and they wanted to get me in touch with the repair center, but the repair center was closed for the day so they told me to call back tomorrow. I will pray that the repair center will change their mind and side with me on this. How can they do something like this?! They sent out a faulty product now they want the consumer to pay for it?

It depends on the country you're in. In some countries, Samsung contracts out repairs, and the repair center doesn't get enough from Samsung for warranty repairs, so they claim that all repairs are in "out of warranty condition". In other countries, you have other avenues. (In the US and the UK, for example, there are Samsung reps in one chain in each [US and UK], and sometimes they can push a repair through.)
Did you try talking to AT&T yet?

Should have been the first step...call AT&T. IF the LCD just stopped working under normal usage, then it is 100% covered. AT&T sends out warranty replacements the same day and you can often get them to overnight it to you (ask politely for priority shipping credit to your account). You'll have 10 days to send the defective device in before they charge you $550 bucks. When they receive your device, they'll inspect it for physical and water damage. I've heard that they ultimately submit them back to Samsung for repair or to be decommissioned. If the device passes AT&T's inspection, then you'll probably never hear from them again.
So since you went the Samsung repair route, they had you send the device into the Samsung repair center. I've been down the path where they state that the device is "out of warranty" due to LCD damage. They'll throw some number at you like $237.00 to repair it or they'll send it back unrepaired. You can ask to speak with a supervisor, and explain how there is no visible damage, its supposed to be a rugged phone, you didn't do anything out of the ordinary, and whatever else to plead your case. $237.00 repair to a phone that cost you $695. Heck, you can probably buy one on Swappa for $350 now. 
You'll need to contact Samsung customer service and work your way up to level 2 support and customer relations. In most cases, customer relations concern is to find a solution that is acceptable to you. Just short of demanding a brand new phone, you'll want to explain your situation in detail. Something like, you like your phone, you like Samsung products, and you would purchase them again. But just like every other device out there, sometimes something goes wrong that was not the consumer's fault. Kindly request that they waive the repair fee and stand by their product that is continually advertised as being rugged and meets IP68 standards.

There are like 3 different places to change settings on this. Mine was doing this and after playing around with it for a while, I got it back going.
Please describe the steps you took because I am still having this issue and don't know how to fix it. At&t and Samsung have been no help to me so far.

replies.text: Are you running 5.1?

thread.text:
1. Sounds and notifications/messages notifications/ tick on vibrations
2. Sounds and notifications/Vibrations/tick on vibrations when ringing
3. Sounds and notifications/Vibrations/vibration intensity/ turn way up
4. Under sounds and notifications/app notifications/choose your messaging app and be sure the notifications aren't blocked
5. Open up stock messaging app, touch more, settings, touch notifications, make sure vibration is ticked on
6. Open up the dialer, touch more, settings, make sure vibrate is on
7. Pull down the notification panel, make sure the sound profile button is there and if not add with edit, tough it a couple of times till it's on vibrate
Once all this is set, get someone to send you a text or dial the AT&T view data usage under contacts so it will send you a text message to test. If it's not working still, restart the phone and test again. If it's still not working, I would suspect something else is set on the phone preventing it. Maybe privacy mode or something. Check back and let us know if this worked.

Yes, 5.1.1. I found out the issue only occurs when using Power Saving Mode - when I turned off Power Saving Mode and restarted the phone I have not had the problem since. But now my phone dies quicker unfortunately because I cannot use the Power Saving Mode. I believe this is just a flaw of the software update where Power Saving Mode turns off all forms of vibrate rather than just the vibrate feedback. I do not believe there is any way to use Power Saving Mode and Vibrate until they fix this in another update. Very dumb in my opinion.

replies.text: If you still have more than 50% juice, you don't need power saving mode. I set power saving mode kick in under 20%, which means my vibration works most of the day.
Good catch!

title: Sudden Battery Power Loss

thread.text:
I have the Galaxy S6 Active. One of the main reasons i got this phone was for the battery life. I purchased my phone in August 2015. I would use my phone all day (5:30 AM to 9:30 PM) and when i went to bed at night (Around 9:30 PM) i would have around 40% battery life left. In the last two weeks i have noticed very fast battery drain. When i would get in my card to drive home after work (5:00 PM) i would have around 20% battery life. What could be causing this? 
I instalaled GSamBattery Monitr as i saw suggested here and the below are images from starting with a 100% charged battery, and using the phone as normal. I took the screen shot when i got to around 20% battery. 
I am trying to figure out if this is a hardware or software issue.
Over time after multiple drains and charges the batteries don't hold up as well. This may be part of the issue.

replies.text: WOW, After only 4 months i would say that is pretty pitiful.
My battery definitely isn't as good as when I first got it. With that being said it still works good though.

I don't think batteries drain that fast after only 4 months of use. 
OP, is it really cold where you work? Cold temps can cause the battery to drain rapidly.
Posted via the Android Central App on the Samsung Galaxy S6 active.

thread.text: I really believe that there is something that RECENTLY started running in the background. There is a "battery life" thread that this is discussed. You are not the only one experiencing this recent onset of excess battery drain.

replies.text: I use package disabler to disable apps I don't use. Maybe the update causes an ATT or Samsung App to drain the battery? Could it be Samsung Pay or one of those ATT drive mode or find your family apps?

thread.text: I agree b/c the change i am talking about happened over night.

Hold volume up-home-power when you turn it on and clear the cache partition. Really helped my battery life. There are threads on here that can help you do this. Doesn't effect your data at all so don't worry about that.
Clearing the cache partition doesn't help this issue.

title: Sound cracking

thread.text:
Hello,
I noticed a thread on here from a while ago with someone having the same problem. Basically when I play videos from Facebook, Snapchat, or even Instagram I notice the sound cracks or sounds like it's skipping/lagging. I updated to 5.1.1 and I also cleared the partition cache and it still persists. 
Is there any other fix to this?
Thanks!
Posted via the Android Central App
Same here. I found that it behaves like this when the volume is low.

I too have the same stuttering audio problem. Even my ringtone and notification sounds stutter sometimes. Noticed it happens most in the youtube app, twitter, and other random video streams. Also noticed once I start a youtube video if I immediately start turning down the volume it starts to stutter, then if I pause the video and restart it, it is fine afterwards.
Uninstalled all music streaming apps, cleared partition cache, to try and troubleshoot the issue.
I don't feel it is a physical speaker problem, since it doesn't happen all the time and videos recorded with the phone have never given the stuttering audio.
Anyone have any ideas? I tried resetting the phone and the audio stuttering is still there, but still only occasionally when playing videos. Surely more people are having this issue.
Does it out ly work for certain audio playback such as crackling noise when playing music only, or for every sound/audio played?

I don't want to jinx it, but I think I narrowed it down to the twitter app. As soon as I uninstalled it the YouTube app played without audio stutter. I readded twitter and the stutter immediately came back in both dead spin twitter videos and the youtube app. Took the twitter app off again and everything's been perfect.

I have tried everything, never had twitter either, and mine still does it.
Posted via the Android Central App
I spoke too soon. Removing the twitter app didn't help. The audio started stuttering a few hours later.
It is fixed now. Had to call warranty support and replace the phone. The new device doesn't have the same problem with the speaker stuttering. Looks like it was a hardware issue.

What did you explain to them
Posted via the Android Central App

The call was surprisingly simple and short. I told her the audio stutters all the time from the speaker but is fine from headphones and bluetooth. Told her I have reloaded the phone multiple times setting it up as a new phone without loading apps. She then said looks like you have tried everything it's a bad phone and started the return process.

thread.text: I agree about the case. I got the supcase unicorn beetle. I wanted protection without bulk and something to protect the camera. Here is the link: http://www.amazon.com/SUPCASE-Unicor...cUvbUpU4910124

I'd get the 64GB. I have the original model and it's not enough memory for my uses. I take A LOT of photos with the Burst action and single photos with HDR enabled, so many of the images have large file sizes. There really is no easy way to get images off the phone without a USB OTG flash drive.

You could use Google photos which backs up your photos and can erase it off your phones memory. You get 15 go free. Or 100 gb for $2 a month. Another option I used was a wireless usb flash drive to transfer my photos there and then delete them on my phone.

Thanks All. For now I'll probably go the manual route - copy/move photos from phone to Laptop every so often. I also deleted videos off the phone (but not Laptop) to make room. Cleared about 10 GB of space that way - though Google Photos sounds like a good option too. 
I would have gone for 64GB if it had been offered, but AT&T only offered the 32GB as an equivalent model.

Samsung S6 Active is a piece of junk. Purchased it for its durability and water resistance. Advertised to be able to be submerged for 30min at 1meter underwater, but after a couple dunks while fishing it no longer works. Neither Samsung or ATT will stand behind their product.

replies.text:
I can't really deny what he's saying here. I wouldn't say that the device itself is junk because I enjoy the camera quality, battery life and screen quality. However, after experiencing issues with durability and water resistance I can definitely feel his pain. It took a bit of effort to force Samsung into honoring its claims of water resistance and durability.
I fault the manufacturer, and NOT ATT, for not acknowledging and updating their policy when it comes to durability and water resistance on this specific device. It appears that physical and water damage applies to all of their phones, including the ones that have a "rugged design", "water resistant up to 1m for 30", and "meets IP68 military standards". The S6 Active is marketed as a device that is capable of enduring a bit more physical handling (obviously not abuse) and at the very least, surviving drops into water. Heck, they even included an "Underwater Mode" in their camera software that tells you how to take shots underwater. 
If you've got an issue after this device being dunked into the water, make Samsung stand by their claim. If the screen breaks or cracks due to a small drop, make an argument and don't take no for an answer. No one said the screen is indestructable, but what the heck is a "rugged" device supposed to be? 
Imagine buying a Jeep and the manufacturer warranty states you'll void it if you go off roading.

title: Bad Lag

thread.text: I was wondering if anyone else experiences lag or freezing and has to fix this by resetting the phone every once in a while. I close all my apps but the RAM usage says that it's being heavily used. Any suggestions?

replies.text: After updating to 5.1 my phone lags a bit and freezes when using the stock internet browser. No problems while on 5.0 though.

thread.text: It is normal for the RAM to be used a lot. Android tries to fill up RAM when idle versus just letting it sit free (like Windows). Clearing RAM just causes the phone to work harder as it will continue to try and fill the phone with more programs for faster processing (a.k.a opening).

title: How do you completely turn off the Samsung Galaxy 6 Active?

thread.text: I need to turn off my phone while over seas. How do I completely turn off my phone so I do not get charged for text messages that come through? I can turn off the data but how to I turn off texting?

Hi, welcome to the forums! You could try a couple of different things. 
Switch aeroplane mode on and just enable WiFi, Bluetooth, etc when you need it. This is what I prefer to do when travelling. 
Switch your SIM card off in the settings or even remove it from the card slot.
I don't know about your carrier, but Verizon allows you to block all texts on the plan.

The only way to turn off texting is to disable it on your mobile plan, but you will lose any texts that are sent to your number while it is disabled. There is no going back from that. Better off having unlimited texting these days.

I traveled through Europe for awhile, and all I needed to do was place the phone in Airplane mode. I picked up a hotspot, as I was there for 3 months, and used the wifi to do all of my communications back home.

title: Trade the Active?

thread.text:
Ok, so this is all hypothetical and just my thoughts after being an Active owner since June. 
I wouldn't call this "full on" regret for purchasing the Active, but I am having some thoughts on where this device stands in terms of support.
Don't get me wrong, the S6 Active is a great device that offers great battery life and physical buttons for those who prefer them. I could make a case for durability, but we've all learned that it contains the same Gorilla Glass as the other devices and still vulnerable as any other device to cracks and shatters. The underwater/IP68 probably isn't a deal breaker for most of us unless we spend most of our time in or around water.
Up until recently, I considered this a Flagship device meaning that it holds top priority for updates, features and support. However, what we've seen leads me to believe that the Active was meant for a niche crowd that aren't concerned with 1. latest updates or 2. Samsung Pay. It has taken a back seat to the S6, S6 Edge, S6 Edge+, and Note 5. 
Would you make an even trade for any one of those devices to be able to have timely updates and Samsung Pay? Would you take the hit on battery life if you went to an S6 or an Edge? 
I wonder if Samsung would entertain the discussion of trading the Active for one of those devices and signing up for Samsung Pay?

I believe you are not the only one that complain about updates and Samsung pay compatibility.
Firstly, one should remember why we choose the active at the first place. The regular S6 was out went the active released and even with custom rom and root. For me, I came from s6 to active just for better battery and it doesn't disappoint me. Also, I get all the premium feature on s6 only except fingerprint scan, which is traded with water proof on active.
Secondly, no root is nobody's fault. We can't blame on devs. If we can pull a bounty for at least 5000, I believe someone would help us. Also, what would 5.1.1 give us different than now. Ram management? That's nothing to do with 5.1.1. 
At the end, I think we are just upset about being trade inequality by Samsung. But whatever we are asking for is not what the active design for.

I agree with everything you said. At this point, what 5.1.1 offers is limited for the Active since we already have decent battery life. The 6.0 update would be a greater improvement for us since it will stretch our battery life to extreme due to Doze. However, AT&T current update process leave a lot to be desired and doesn't give me much hope regarding the 6.0 update. I don't even mind the delay if they just kept us updated on the current progress. But with the mixed messages that people are getting (That I blame on AT&T reps not knowing anything and just saying whatever they can to get rid of our questions), it is very hard to stay hopeful

I am one of those completely happy with this phone. It's the perfect size, it's rugged and needs no case, the screen an camera are great and the battery life is fantastic,
As for updates, 5.1.1, meh. I have no lag or any other issues. No Samsung pay is no big deal either. Now 6.0 for the reason Mizu mentioned would be great..
I had the S3 which I loved. I went through the G2, G3 and Note 4 and there was always something I didn't like with those. Traded the Note 4 for this and love it.

Found something last night stating the S6A would receive Android 6.0 1st quarter 2016. Forgot to grab the link, & to be honest would trust the info more if it were posted via A.C. So just throwing it out there.
But the rumor mill is also churning about the S7 details being released in Jan with the device being out in Feb. True or click bait? Have no idea. Maybe Samsung is changing their game a bit?

replies.text: Here's the linkAT&T’s Samsung Galaxy S6 Active Android 6.0 Marshmallow Update : Trending News : Venture Capital Post
That's not real. Have been discussed over other thread.

thread.text: Reading the forums before purchasing the Active, I went in with the understanding that updates weren't going to happen as often as the S6. I'm okay with that. But I did a lot of research about this device before purchase. The battery life tipped the scale for the Active. I don't care for a fingerprint scanner or Samsung Pay. I never used Apple Pay when I had an iPhone.

The battery life is pretty sweet. I don't carry around my external battery pack unless I'm going to be away from a power source for a long time. Even with heavy usage, I'm still at 30-40% by the end of the day (8am-10pm) 
Updates are coming. We are at 5.1.1 right now, and that's the only one since launch. 
Samsung Pay is now available for the Active. And if you activate the app on your phone between now and Dec. 31st. you'll get a $50 Best Buy e-gift card. I synced up my Amex Card, but have no intention of actually using it for purchases. Its cool to have as an emergency card though.

I definitely love the Battery life on the S6A - especially since I'm a moderately light user of the phone. I got it mostly charged (97%) on Wednesday, went through all the setup, customization, and downloading apps, leaving it on overnight (which I never did with my G3 previously), and was at 19% today (Saturday) before charging. 
No interest in Samsung Pay.
The two biggest drawbacks so far for me:
1) No Expandable Memory. If they can figure out how to waterproof the SIM card slot, they should be able to do the same for an SD/MicroSD card... it just means I'll be careful with taking videos as they can take up a good portion of memory.
2) Not compatible with Samsung Keis 3. I'm not much of a cloud person (no idea how to even set it up...) and would love a way to simply back up the phone on my laptop. I know there is Samsung Switch now - but there are 3 versions of it - no clue which to get for basic backup functionality.

title: S6 Drop Distance

thread.text: Was at a hockey game taking a picture, phone got knocked out of my hand, fell 3-4 feet, and then stopped functioning. Is it dead? Or is this fixable? The screen has a barely noticeable crack in the top-left. Pretty disappointed if this is the durability they are advertising.

Welcome to Android Central! Does it still make sounds and vibrate? If so, then it's probably just the screen that's damaged. But if nothing happens at all, perhaps an internal connection came loose, or there was damage to the motherboard.. The thing about drops (especially onto a hard surface, which is what I'm assuming it was, since you were at a hockey game) is that the way it falls and strikes the floor can be more important than how far it falls. If it falls in such a way that the shock of impact is concentrated (like landing on the corner) rather than more evenly distributed (like flat on its back), then the likelihood of damage is higher.
The only response I get is when I hold the home button, volume, and power and I get a flash for a fraction of a second and that's it.
You probably need to bring it to a repair shop to further diagnose the problem.
So it rang this morning with the custom ring tone I had set. So that is promising, hoping it's just a loose cable. Going to take it in hopefully today.

So the diagnosis is a cracked lcd panel which requires replacement. Estimates are running in the $350-$400 range from local repair shops, none of whom carry the part in stock. Looking at Samsung for options.
Dang, that's steep! I'm used to hearing about a $100-200 range. I suppose it's because you have an Active, and not the regular S6. Good luck!

replies.text:
I've had a similar hairline crack in my screen which required an lcd panel replacement through Samsung. I was quoted at $237.00 for a replacement. Although their site clearly states that it is $199.00 for out of warranty/damaged lcd repair for the S6, I only payed $70 for the replacement. Here's what I did:
1.Take photos of the device, find your receipt, and make notes of what happened when your device stopped working (In other words, get your ducks in a row before you call for support.)
2. Follow their repair instructions for mailing in the device. Keep track of the package and when it is delivered to the repair center. In my case, they take several days to actually check the device in after receiving it. 
3. You'll get a call back when they've looked at the device and made their assessment. They'll demand payment within a business day or two or they will mail it back to you unrepaired. (The voicemail i received didn't go into the details of their assessment and almost seemed threatening. "If you don't pay up, we're not going to fix this and we'll send it back to you broken.")
4. Here's where I made my case. I purchased this device based on its advertised features of being rugged and waterproof and capable of keeping up with someone who has an active lifestyle. As my pictures indicate, I did not abuse the device or do anything outside of normal operation to compromise its ability to function. I really didn't understand how a minor drop could render the device inoperable especially if there are little to no signs of damage. 
I made my case to Level I and Level II support, and eventually spoke to a manager at the repair center who adjusted the final bill to $70. Be persistent, ask for an explanation and push for a reasonable resolution. Sure, the device would not have stopped working if you didn't drop it, but is it not reasonable to expect this type of device to survive drops?
I reluctantly paid, but $70 is better than $237. And I'm not sharing this to encourage you to "get over" on Samsung. It really is about demanding them to stand by their advertised product and treat it appropriately. No, they didn't advertise the s6 active as drop-proof, however, they market it as being a rugged device that meets IP68 standards (some military battery of tests regarding waterproofing and dust proofing). This would lead the consumer to believe that the device is significantly more durable than a device with glass backing.

thread.text: wouldn't insurance cover this?
Excellent approach. It takes preparation and patience, but that's what it often takes to get the best outcome.

Thanks for the info, I'll see what they do. I'll share my unbelievable story of how this came to be. Also known as how the S6 Active fought a Teddy Bear and lost.
While volunteering at a Portland Winterhawks children charity event, Teddy Bear Toss, (there was a link here but I don't have enough posts to post it, so google Winterhawks Teddy Bear Toss the top result is the news release from OregonLive's website that has it), I was pulling this phone out to capture the moment. I was struck by one of the many bears (as I was near the access point to collect bears), causing the phone to fall three feet and land on the ground. Seeing no visible damage, I picked it up, attempted to press the home button, and noticed that the screen stayed black (later I found that the phone was still operational, I just couldn't hear anything with the phone in silent mode.) Through this process, I have been able to receive calls, make calls (via bluetooth), and receive texts (playback through my truck). However, upon further inspection, the LCD screen underneath the glass had a small crack causing the screen to fail, however, it is important to note, that there is absolutely no external damage whatsoever.
Was this the culprit?
Witnesses have placed him in/around the area, but not in the immediate vicinity.

title: S6 Active Durability? Is it less, equally, or more durable than average phones?

thread.text:
Hey Everybody, 
I am seriously considering the S6 active. I like changing up phones every few months and am thinking about giving Sammy a shot again. I was thinking the S6 but just can't deal with the battery life. I like the note 5 (currently trying it out via samsung test drive) but I don't use the pen and am looking for something more unique from what I have done before (I owned the note 4 previously) and it costs about $150 extra used over the active. 
As a result, the S6 active sounds like a fun option. I don't really care that it is more bulky or plastic, or downright ugly. I will gladly trade those for 35% more battery than the S6. The durability is just a nice extra. 
However, my question is this:
Most places I have looked for reviews (tech sites and Amazon), there are tons and tons of people saying that the front glass shattered easily. Most mention that the cracking started near the physical buttons which appears to be flanked by relatively narrow strips of glass. Do you guys with experience with the phone think that this phone is at least as durable as a regular phone (such as the S6)? My gut instinct is that people simply expected too much from the rugged claims made by AT&T/Samsung. However, there is a nagging piece of me that keeps looking at the glass around the buttons and thinking that it looks awful fragile. 
Any thoughts or comments would be greatly appreciated!
P.S. I plan on using a case with this phone. Nothing major like an otterbox but something that I would use on any other phone and can dampen impact a bit.

replies.text:
Do a you tube search. Tons of videos. Check out the one where the dude plays hockey with the s6 active as the puck. Or the drone dropping it. That should answer your question.
I have both and like the s6 active for the battery life and to take camping. It is tougher, no question but if you get a speck candy grip case you should be good with a s6 if you do not need water resistance. 
Posted via my S6 Active with Samsung Pay!

thread.text:
I've never owned a regular S6 so I couldn't compare the two. However, I can chime in and say that the durability on my particular device has NOT met my expectations. My 4 year old son cracked the screen easily by biting it like a dinosaur. After the repair, the internal seals were not set properly and water entered the device after getting splashed by a sprinkler. I've seen another member on here post about a 3 foot drop that damaged the LCD. In my opinion, the plastic casing on the phone is not enough protection against drops as the shock can destroy the screen and/or internals.
My suggestion is to grab a hybrid case that offers more protection than a bumper or shell case.

Thanks man, I really appreciate your feedback. It is such a shame that they didn't do a better job protecting this phone. I assume you had to pay for the repair out of pocket? Most reviews I have read said that Samsung would not stand behind their durability claims.

Occasionally, I will use my active without a case, but I HATE scuffs and minor things like that on my phone, so I have an iBlason case on it. It's pretty bulky, but I have a slimmer case coming from Amazon soon. I'm not very hard on my phones, but I like being worry free about splashes of water. My phone has yet to take a fall onto the sidewalk, etc. but I think even a small fall and hitting just the right spot would still shatter this screen.

With my previous phones, I have never had a drop. With the S6 Active, it has withstood 3 different drops onto concrete and tile from pocket level. Just a few minor scratches and that is it. Great durability.

I'm using an Evocel Hybrid Armor Protector Case from Amazon for $10. Does a great job at protecting the device.

title: Galaxy S6 Active Update 5.1.1 Vibrates, how can I stop it?

thread.text:
I just made an account here and don't know if this is the right place to post, but here I go:
Ever since I updated to Android 5.1.1 I've had a weird problem with my phone vibrating. 
Most of the time, it just doesn't vibrate. When I change the volume from sound to vibrate, the phone vibrates as it does usually. But when I get phone calls/text messages/most other notifications on vibrate, the phone wouldn't vibrate at all. I use Kik messenger a lot, and will never get any vibrations with it, even if I have sound on. With sound on, it just makes the sound and no vibration.
When I go into settings, and vibration intensity, the vibration for notifications and feedback work when I try to adjust it, but for "incoming call" there is no vibration. Also, the setting where it says "Vibrate while ringing" is completely grayed out, but switched as "on". Even when I change the vibration pattern, there is no vibration. 
I dialed *#0*# and clicked "vibration" and the screen goes black and there is no vibration. 
Don't know what else to say.... Anyone got any ideas?

OK there is a setting that turns on when you update. I've had this problem too. Go into settings>accessibility>notification reminder. Toggle it off. also settings>search(top right corner)>notification reminder(scroll to find it). Then toggle it off. Hope this helps!

title: Question about onedrive on s6 active

Can't say for certain if the 100GB OneDrive promo is still active or not, but I can say that if it is, MS's changes to OneDrive won't affect it. The changes apply only for free storage; this promo is the equivalent of 'buying' extra storage, which will give you 100GB for, I believe, two years. After that time is up and your promo expires, you'd be downgraded to whatever the current free tier is at the time (currently 5GB).

Yup, if you select so in the Settings, you can get previews of messages in the lockscreen as well as quick actions. Some apps let you have pop-up message windows like iOS.

title: International Usage?

thread.text:
Hey all, new member here. I have an AT&T S6 Active. Love the phone, it's remarkably rugged for a ham fisted troglodyte such as myself.
Anyway, I am taking the family to London and Southern England over the Christmas holiday, and I had neglected to look into international phone usage until this morning. Seems that AT&T wants gazillions of dollars for the privilege of paying them gazillions more to use my phone overseas. I don't want to do much, other than be able to receive emergency phone calls and maybe send texts/make calls to wish my immediate and extended family a merry Christmas. Websites aren't super helpful, as they all seem Hell-bent on selling me something without getting too deep into the details of whether or not this is even going to meet my wants and needs.
Basically, is my phone factory unlocked, or do I have to somehow unlock it? Is my best option the AT&T international roaming plan, or can I unlock it and use a UK SIM card?

A cheap UK SIM would probably be your best bet if you're not looking at an extended (months) stay. Vodaphone or Orange would probably be your best bet. There's a website that shows whether a particular model phone works on a particular carrier, and what features work/don't.WillMyPhoneWork.net - Check if your phone works on a network
As for unlocking, as long as your bill is paid up AT&T will probably send you an unlock code/instructions free. Call them to find out.

So the good news is that AT&T's better than it used to be. tl;dr is $30 for 120GB of data, $60 for 300MB of data, or $120 for 800MB. (We keep up with all that here: International data overseas: How the U.S. carriers stack up | Android Central) So if you want to just hop off the plane and have things work, there you go. I usually at least spring for the 
But call AT&T first and see if they'll give you the unlock code. If your account's in good standing you might get lucky (GS6A is still pretty new, though, and they get wonky about that stuff.)
And if you're flying into LHR, you can get a SIM at a vending machine before you leave for pretty cheap.

I bought the $60 plan for my trip last summer and all worked out great. I probably could have gotten by with the smaller plan but felt it was better to buy what I did rather than chance not having enough and really get gouged.

Thanks for the input, fellas. I really appreciate it.
Now, as for the UK SIM cards, will those enable me to call to the US if needed without exorbitant fees? It sounds like most of them allow for incoming calls without killing my budget.

To clear your cache:
Shut down your phone. 
Hold the power, volume up, and home buttons at the same time until the phone boots into recovery mode. Then use the volume keys to navigate and select the clear cache option by pressing the power button. It won't take long. Then, use the volume buttons again to select reboot option.

title: Samsung Galaxy S6 Active video quality

thread.text: I have searched but can't find any other threads about this, why is the video quality so poor on the S6 Active when sending or receiving a a video within a text? I tried the stock messaging app and the Textra app, and the video quality is awful. Is there a way to fix this, or another app I can use that would be better? Thanks!

The quality of your video is reduced in text because of the compression needed to reduce the file size. 
You can get around this by uploading the video to a cloud service such as Google Photos and then sending someone the link to the file, as opposed to sending them the file itself.

title: How do I transfer contacts and texts from my Lumia 1520 to Galaxy S6 Active?

thread.text: i don't have a clue
If your lumina supports NFC you can do the transfer that way. In the S6 manual there should be instructions on different ways to transfer data over.

See what file export formats the Lumia supports. Google Contacts supports importing csv files from "Outlook, Outlook Express, Yahoo! Mail, Hotmail, Eudora and some other apps". Once you do that and your phone syncs, you'll have your contacts on your S6.

title: Galaxy S5 - How to download full email message for reading offline in the standard email app?

thread.text: Hi - I am using the built-in email app on my new Samsung Galaxy S5 for my corporate email account and would like to change the settings so that the text of my emails are automatically downloaded so I can read them without tapping "Load More", especially when I have no service on the subway. title: S6 Active just updated 5.1.1 and notifications will not stop, what can I do?

thread.text:
S6 Active on AT&T. Just updated to 5.1.1. The phone is vibrating and audible notifications while I have all notifications off. I put the phone into "mute". I even put it into "Airplane" mode and it still was setting off notifications.
Any ideas?
Welcome to Android Central! Try wiping the cache partition: https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21095

title: Activity Zone Problem

thread.text: When I open Activity zone, I'm only getting a white screen. I just used the flashlight yesterday and today I've got nothing. Already tried Force close with data/cache clearing and a reboot. I'm stumped.

I am having same issue. Just started yesterday.
Posted via the Android Central App

Just tried mine, works normally, so not all of them are affected. Good luck, hope you figure it out, you may want to try a soft reset, no information or photos will be lost (Power and volume down keys pressed at the same time until phone restarts).

I'm having the same problem. Started yesterday around noon I think. I open the activity zone and a white screen is displayed. I then have to close it. Occasionally it crashes before I can close it. Even after a soft reset, force stop and clearing the cached data it still doesn't work.
Has anyone come up with a fix for this? I was finally able to download Facebook and now this?

Working fine after getting the ATT 5.1.1 update tonight. Surprising the Activity zone just stopped before the software update was even started. Oh well, working now. Guess I'll have to wait about a year for Marshmallow. 1 bad thing about ATT and the bloatware.
mine dropped dead as well. My screen is white, and I don't know how to update or remove it.
I noticed this problem a few days ago on my new phone. I took it into the AT & T store and they had no clue. Glad to see there is a fix. Waiting for the 719MB download to finish. Fingers crossed!
The update did not work for me.
I got this problem before and I used Package Disabler to disable it, reboot, then enable. Back to normal for me.

I just did that as you said and it didn't work. I can see on the window that opens when I check the Activity Zone checkbox, that the package size is 0 MB and the RAM memory usage is 0.00 MB, and the Package Data Size is 0.02 MB. So basically it looks like the program isn't even there. But there are others that show 0 MB also.....
I just tried it again and it IS working now.  Very strange. Thanks!

You need to open Samsung Milk Videos and acknowledge the disclosure. Basically, Samsung is no longer providing the service and the disclosure acknowledgement is causing Activity Zone to hang on launch.
This is the second time that Activity Zone has gone awry. The other time it was fixed by updating Samsung Milk Music. Seems as if the "Milk" services causes the majority of the hangups.
I did that the went back to the activity zone and still a white screen. Tried Mike Music and it blacked out on me?

I just went into the play store, updated milk music, restarted the phone and now mil music and the activity zone is working.
Thanks for the info

title: Guess I'm going to leave AT&T if we don't get 5.1.1 by the end of the month.

I know some people say it works fine for them, but mine regularly freezes when I go to unlock it. The screen will turn on and off multiple times and I can't even swipe to unlock. Other times apps are non-responsive or take too long to open. There have been times where I cannot respond to a message for close to a minute because the phone decides to have a brain freeze. Memory leaks, TouchWiz, or whatever the reason for the poor performance, I hope 5.1.1 fixes it at least a little bit.

Having mixed feelings at this point. I'm well past the return period for my Active so that is out of the question. I'm not really interested in trading, or selling, as I'd probably lose even more money with the NEXT program. 
Here's what I still LOVE about this phone:Beautiful displayAwesome battery lifeRugged look and feelGreat camera
I would have commented on the water-resistance/proof, but that is VERY SUSPECT right now. I've had the device repaired for a small crack in the screen, got it back and then experienced water damage while at a water park. (I firmly believe that the phone was not resealed properly.) Now that I have it back, I will not be testing its water resistance AND unfortunately I will never fully experience the UNDERWATER MODE in the camera app.
Here is what I DON'T like:Samsung's reluctance to address water issues despite UNDERWATER MODE and IP68 ratingsThe Active is a version of the S6 flagship device, which should receive the same attention when it comes to updatesNo Samsung Pay?Minor lag experienced at random

http://forum.xda-developers.com/show....php?t=3224984
Posted via the Android Central App on my GS6 Active

Law, I've taken it in the water, The pool a couple times, used it in the rain, rinsed it off in the sink. I've also dropped it a few times and other than a couple marks on the outside case, it is fine. It has lived up to the IP68 ratings for me. That being said, the GG4 glass on the front is no better than any other phone with GG4, so it would break just as easy if it dropped onto a jagged surface. I found the small raised lip around the screen does help protect it a little bit from a flat fall right on the screen.
I'm disappointed it doesn't have Samsung pay, but without a fingerprint reader or the ability to pay using a magnetic reader, Google Pay does all the same things.
I haven't had much random lag recently. I have observed one thing though, The lag does seem to happen when I am not at home and connected to wifi. 
One other complaint, I forget how much free space the phone started with, but I have found the 32 GB to go very quick as well. There is so much bloat on Samsung phones. Like really, I can't uninstall Uber? That's crazy.

So the S5 is now getting 5.1.1 on ATT while the Active is stuck on 5.0.2. Really looking forward getting my 64GB Nexus 6p and ending this little Samsung detour.

I have the same problems. Had an S6 with Verizon, came to AT&T less than a month ago. While my signal has been great compared to Verizon, my S6 Active is noticeably different in its performance. I've been complaining about issues since day 4, so much so that AT&T is letting me walk away from my contract completely. Now that I've factory reset my Active, I have been very happy with the performance. No lag so far. I don't know if it was a particular app that I had running. Now I just add apps one at a time as I need them, so if it starts behaving badly again, I should be able to pinpoint the cause. I am probably going to return the Nexus 6P this week. It is a good phone, but the Active has a better camera and I actually appreciate some of the TouchWiz features on the Active. No 60fps recording on the 6P, no OIS, no HDR video. thread.text:
Hi I have an Active and while it basically is a great phone, I am really frustrated with the lack of updates. . . and also its kind of crummy voice phone quality… But your thread is about the lock screen and active key ;-) 
I tried your situation on my phone --setting active key enabled on the lock screen -even though I normally don't have that enabled.
Oh, before my results, I would offer one comment on @Hanamizi's results. I would say that he is probably completely correct! However, he does not have a real security lock enabled. Swipe is not a security measure. So It can't be compared to password, face recognition, pattern, etc. 
Based on my testing tonight, if you have any real security measure -like pattern or password, etc., even with the active key enabled, When you press the “active key” while the lock screen is showing, you FIRST will have to enter the password, or pattern, or visual, etc. 
Anyway, that's how it works on my Active -using either pattern or password. I suspect that’s the normal Samsung implementation. 
Oddly enough, even with a pattern lock screen set, I have two options showing on my lock screen -use the phone or use the camera. 
-	When I swipe the phone I am "allowed" to make an "emergency phone call" only. 
-	When I swipe the camera I am allowed to take pictures. 
In both cases I don't have to enter the password! That makes it more convenient than the active key –if you have a locked screen! For example, my Active key is normally set to camera (quick press) and phone (long press), and if the screen is locked I see that I would have to enter the pattern first to use either! ;-( 
Actually, I don’t really have that problem since I have my Gear S watch on my hand --and it is associated with the phone -so the phone is automatically unlocked when in contact with the phone. When I I press the active key for phone or photo I get to those apps normally without issue. 
(In order to test the lock screen, I actually turned off my watch -so the lock screen was simulating most common users conditions).
In short, the Active key really does not add much to the lock screen –you still have to do your unlock measure. Try placing apps on the unlock screen –since I see that I can use photo and (emergency) phone when locked –even without unlocking. . .
Hope this helps! Have a great day!
Mark

replies.text:
You got it. That's exactly how the active key works. And I think there's still convenience by using the active key even with security setting. It should save you at least 1 extra action of opening apps(1 tap or 1 scrolling etc.) 
If one have smart lock setup, that's even better. Like if you connected your phone to car Bluetooth, active key setup for opening Google Maps. That should help your safety driving a lot.

title: How can I stop my Galaxy S6 Active screen from freezing?

thread.text: I've had my Galaxy S6 Active less than 24 hours and have already had issues with the screen freezing up and not recognizing my input when typing on the keyboard during texts, swiping to unlock or when trying to open apps. So frustrating! How can I fix this?

I had the same issue. Sometimes the keyboard is very laggy. Other times the screen would also freeze up during an unlock. It would usually show the wallpaper, then go back to being locked, shut the screen on, then go back on. Sometimes it wouldn't recognize swipe to unlock. For the most part, my phone has been behaving pretty well lately. I did 2 things that might be helping. I did a factory reset and when I logged back into Google, I told it not to restore my applications. So far I've just add the applications as I need them. I can't point out the culprit, really none of my apps should cause that kind of lag, yet the lag was occurring. I also didn't disable anything with Package Disabler either.
Usually when it lags pretty bad I end up restarting my phone and that usually fixes it. People have said a factory reset can help fix it too but I don't feel like going through that hassle.

I would recommend installing the Google Keyboard from the play store. I installed it as soon as I set up the phone, and have not had any issues. It's a great, accurate keyboard with incredibly accurate swipe features built in as well, if you're into that.

Sorry to hear but the only thing that helped for me is a factory reset. The good thing is that I haven't needed to do it since. The phone is a champ now! (Except the RAM management, but it is bearable)

title: Package Disabler

thread.text: Guys, pay the $1.50 for Package Disabler on the play store, and start going to town disabling things you don't need. Their " Disable all bloatware " option is too aggressive, and you'll have to re-enable several things, but once I was done, I regularly had 1 GB free of RAM and the phone now runs like a well oiled machine! Huge difference. No more lag loading programs, no more sluggishness that made me wonder why my s5 performed better. Game changer!
Interesting, but I'm curious--does it disable things that you can also disable in the App Manager, or does it do things that you can't otherwise do in the stock menu?
So you paid for something you can just do yourself by disabling the app?

This does WAY more than disable just the at&t apps, etc. This goes deeper into the phone. I disabled lots of unneeded services too. Don't judge unless you've tried it out. The free version let's you disable around ten things, I ended up disabling about 50 things.
Also, you MIGHT need to re-enable everything before a system update, but you can export your settings, and import them back after the system update.

Can you give us a few examples of some of the deeper stuff you can disable? It's intriguing that you can do this without rooting. Of course, one must be cautious about the things you disable, in case it causes problems--is there any easy way to keep track of it using the app?
And that's just down to the M's

It's a great app, I can finally disable Emergency Alerts, My Magazine, Flipboard and Kids Mode
Sent from my SM-N900V using Tapatalk Pro

Just downloaded it. Enabled all my disabled apps and disabled through this app. Weird that the ATT bloatware doesn't come up listed as bloatware by the package disabler app.
Found this info as well which can be used with package disabler.http://androidforums.com/threads/all...t-list.871115/

After I disabled all the magenta-colored "unnecessary" services PD identified, I had an intermittent issue of my Samsung clear case not shutting down the screen when closing. When I re-enabled all the "bloatware" it was fine. Not a major problem but it's a nice feature. And the Samsung account service is bloatware??

title: S6 Active to Nexus 6P video comparison

thread.text: I bought the Nexus 6P and now I'm trying to decide if I'm keeping it. I am realizing I really like my Active and now that I factory reset it, it is behaving very well. I'm just adding an app at a time as I need them, so if one causes slowdown, I will be able to pinpoint it. I digress, I created a comparison of 1080p videos taken with both the S6 Active and the Nexus 6P. The Active can record HDR video at 1080p which the 6P cannot. Despite that, the 6P video was decent. It was better than Active with HDR off, but a little less bright than the Active with HDR on. I picked scenes where there was a lot of light and a lot of shadows. I noticed in most normal lighting situations, HDR doesn't make much difference. The Active can also record 1080p at 60ps, but for this test I just stuck with 30fps. I overall prefer having the options that the Active has. Wish the Active had come with 64GB though. Its really easy to fill up the free space on the Active.

I would love to know what you decided in the end. Like you, I was having troubles with the Active and factory resetting it yesterday made most of the problems disappear. But the Nexus 6P is very tempting with the quick update compared to our reliance on AT&T.

title: Wake Screen by Waving Hand

thread.text:
You can turn on waking your screen by Waving your hand over it in the settings menu. 
Settings > accessibility > dexterity and interactions > gesture wake up
Pretty handy feature considering we don't have double tap to wake or have to press the buttons. Putting your phone in and out of your pocket doesn't affect it since it has to lay flat to work.
Thanks for the tip!

I've found a third party app that takes this a little further. Gravity Screen
I had a MotoX (2013) and OnePlus One before this phone. Both of them had cool features for screen wake (proximity or double-tap). Gravity screen works well for me as I also use ACDisplay for my lockscreen. The S6 is VERY similar to how my MotoX used to work and I LOVE it. Battery drain is minimal and accidental wakes are pretty rare. 
I can now just take it out of my pocket for wake, and then put it back to put it to sleep "Look ma, no button pressing"!

title: Love/Hate the physical buttons

thread.text:
I came from a OnePlus One and was a little weary of the physical buttons on the Active. After owning it for the past 2 months I've had a love/hate opinion of them. I do love that I don't mistakenly hit any of the buttons during gaming or from within apps. But there are times (in car dock, on Qi charger, or holding/using with one hand) that it takes quite some force to push the buttons. While on the Qi charger, to press one of the physical front buttons, it will knock it off the charger. The biggest annoyance is when using the phone with one hand it takes a bit of adjustment of the phone to reach and physically push the buttons - mostly for the back button for me, which I use a lot since it is difficult to reach the upper left hand corner for the 'soft back'.
Anyway, I went in search of a software app to give me software buttons. I wanted something lightweight, non-intrusive, simple and mostly free.
I downloaded a few to evaluate:https://play.google.com/store/apps/d....navigationbarhttps://play.google.com/store/apps/d...os.aiogestureshttps://play.google.com/store/apps/d....handysoftkeys
I've settled on Navigation Bar - Soft Keys, but not sure I completely like it. It takes between 50-100mb RAM (I'd be fine with 50-60mb), and I like the implementation by Handy softkeys where the trigger point disappears until the screen is touched. The opacity of the trigger on NavBar-Softkeys can be set, but the persistent icon is a little distracting. I could never get AllInOne Gestures to work, for some reason, I couldn't get it to 'enable' in my accessibility settings.
Any other suggestions?

replies.text: Can I ask what you do with it in the car dock? This is the most frustrating thing to me about the S6 Active is that there is no more car mode that will announce and read texts to me, or allow me to answer a call with just voice. Very frustrating to come from an S4 that did that very well.

thread.text: In troubleshooting a bad Recent Apps button on mine, I found someone recommending "All In One Gestures". I tried it... and I like it a lot. You can assign functions to the hard keys (single tap or long press), the status bar (double tap), or swiping for up to 12 areas of the screen. I just tried it to see if I could pin down my button problem - but button problem aside, I will continue using it - very cool.

replies.text:
Thanks, I'll give it AIOGestures try.
After a whole night of using exclusively NavigationBar - SoftKeys, I like it a lot! My muscle memory is slowly getting used to the onscreen softkey and I find myself not pressing the physical keys as much. 'One-handing' the device is really easy now and I don't have to shift around my grip to depress the physical keys as much. I also think that in the long-run, it'll save some 'wear and tear' of the physical keys. The persistent icon can be adjusted in opacity so while it is there and kind of annoying, I don't mind it now since it brings me awesome functionality.
In some very non-scientific testing, the app is currently running at 10mb ram and the majority it goes between 40-60mb. I've checked on it maybe 10-15 times through the application manager. It was 100+mb twice, but it doesn't seem to be too heavy. What apps do other people use to monitor CPU/Battery/Ram of a particular app over time?

thread.text:
After a few days with Navigation Bar-Softkeys, I grew tired of the persistent icon and an extra tap to get the softkeys to come up. RAM and battery drain was no problem for that software package.
I've moved on to All in One Gestures last night and I already think this will be a much better solution. I couldn't install it at first, I had to download the Google text-to-speech module from the Play store so my accessibility settings could allow AIOGestures to work properly.
After configuring the offscreen swipes for Home (swipe bottom), Back (swipe from left or right), and multitask (swipe from either bottom corner), the device is much more usable with one hand and even better not needing to use the physical buttons. AIOGestures also offers a bunch of other options for configuring other buttons (long presses, and double taps). It will even learn the active button and you could configure it from within this app. 
So far, this has been the best solution for me. However, some of the Google Play Store reviews mention a big battery drain, so I'm going to monitor it. However, since this brings such good functionality to the phone, I would have to see significant drain not to use it.

Mostly just maps, google music (or podcasts), and an occasional call.
But using the front keys takes a bit of force to press. Not a huge deal, but sometimes it would change my HVAC settings since i use a vent mounted dock that overlaps with some of my HVAC controls in car.
Yah, the MotoX would announce incoming texts which was nice, but I also use ACDisplay which will wake the screen and give me a MotoX like notification so I can glance at the text. Otherwise, it can just wait. Using GoogleNow can help me call someone or dictate a message, but yeah, you have to still wake the screen and hold down the physical home button.

thread.text: It seems likely that you have an app (or combination of apps) that is causing the problem.

Well, mine only lasted for about a month before a full factory reset. 
This time around, I was a little more selective on what I installed. The phone was at a pretty 'stable' state as far as my regular apps, when I noticed the bad stutter. It was infact, the same time Hangouts 4.0 was updated on my phone. When it was combined with my SMS/MMS, it rendered the phone unusable when a group MMS conversation was happening. I removed SMS/MMS from Hangouts and all was 'better'. Moved on to Textra (which is pretty awesome by the way). However, not soon after that, experienced the really bad stutter, tried uninstalling some apps one by one, but didn't get better.

thread.text: I came from a OnePlus One and before that a MotoX 2013. The OnePlus One was just too big for me, as far as 'pocketing' it. I don't have super slim pants, but it would dig into me when sitting so I would constantly have it out. The Active has been nice overall, especially the hardware aspects. The software now feels fine, day one, after my reset. We'll see how often I have to do this, but so far, it is blazing fast again.

Well this is kind of a bummer, but I'm glad to hear I'm not the only one. I didn't think I've gone too crazy installing apps, but when I have a nice down day I'll do the factory reset as well. The phone isn't unusable by any stretch, but it's certainly not what I remember when I first got it. Biggest frustration has been the camera not launching or taking 10's of seconds at times. Used to be no-time flat with the double click of the home button.

Can we start a conversation on what the most painless way of factory restoring and getting back up and running since this may be regular way to get the otherwise awesome S6 Active back to usable. Again, we don't have a way to root, so I'm guessing Titanium is not going to be an option.System Settings:I use Nova Launcher Prime and I can export my settings to Dropbox.When I factory restored, I chose the 'setup as new'. Would it be better to restore from a Google saved backup set? (it would restore some system settings, saved wifi networks, and apps - with app data?I use a program called MyBackup Pro that has an option of restoring system settings, but haven't tried it as I wanted as 'clean' of an install as I could. I'll try that the next time.Other suggestions?AppsI restored one by one out of the Play Store, tedious, but that way I could be selectiveIf you don't 'Set phone up as new', then I'm guessing the OS will restore your apps from the last known Google backupAgain, MyBackupPro has an option to backup/restore my apps. I'm not sure that I have enough space in my Dropbox to backup all the apks, but I may try this.ContactsI used MyBackupPro, but got tons of duplicates, but I think it is partly because over the years, they just built up from other restoring options. I had to download a duplicate contacts deletion app to restore.I think in the past AT&T had some kind of contacts manager, anyone use this to backup and restore?I guess if you sync your contacts to Google, they can be synced back no problem.SMS/MMSI used MyBackup Pro, it worked pretty well, except I think my contacts were so screwed up, when I imported, some MMS group conversations were separated (the history)Photos/VideosI keep all my stuff 'auto synced' to Google Photos, so no biggie for me to lose local copies
That's about all the stuff I use my phone for, most of my data is really in the cloud between Dropbox/Google Drive and other services, there isn't much local to my phone so I don't really mind doing the factory reset every month or two. Now if I could have a one-touch restore after a factory reset, I'd pay for that.
Suggestions/Comments?

You use anything like clean master and/or CM security? I use those to clean all the junk off my phone... Also I was having major decrease in battery life. I use usage manager to keep eye on things and noticed the battery would say 100% charged but usage manager showed the battery was only charging about 90%. Almost bought a new charger, but then i tried plugging charger into a different outlet, not a power strip, and now it's back to normal. Getting 26-30 hrs on battery before getting the 15% charge notice...
JPerks SGS6A

Since then I have been using it more and get down around to 30-40% range at the end of the day. That is with a lot of customizing and playing with different launchers etc.

I been getting around 3-4 SOT on average, with the best being 5 hrs and the worst being 1hr.... As you can guess, this battery life is fairly disappointing, considering what some of you guys have mentioned and shown. I am trying to decide whether to go into the Best Buy to get an exchange before my exchange period is over. 
In terms of my usage, I am mostly on facebook, reddit, email, and messenger each day. I also have a smartwatch connected to my phone. I also have the Material design theme installed. I am seeing about 2-3% drain on standby. I have also tried playing youtube videos for an hour, and it drains about 15% in that hour. I have been uninstalling/disabling most apps that is a battery drain, and it barely squeezed out more battery life. I have also restricted background data to a few apps ( in particular, Google Play Service) to try to reduce some of the background processing that can cause battery drain.

(NOTE: My biggest hardware gripe is that i wish they put the speaker on the top front. Seems like there was plenty of room to me.)

I have had my S6 Active for 2 weeks and used it as my daily driver for that time. I have several other devices most recently a S6. I must say the S6 Active has grown on me. I like the size, heft, the amazing screen and camera, all the things that make the S6 a flagship device including **** kicking battery life. About the only complaint many have about the S6 is the battery life and the S6 Active really fills that void with a 3500 mAh battery. The buttons take a few days to get used to but they are fine and durable. talking on Att to another HD voice capable device is superb! (if you have the service in your area) I had the S4 Active for a while and it was in no way as capable as the S6 Active. Kudos to Samsung for refining this device into an awesome rugged device that can outperform other flagships without breaking a sweat and to ATT for sticking with the Active series devices! 
I feel like I have a great set up. I use a CIMO TPU case for extra grip and to protect from scratches and a seidio G3 surface holster which fits the S6 Active with a TPU case very well for when i want to wear the phone on my pant or shorts.

I currently have the S5 Active and will be getting the 6 this week for the same reason I got the S5. Unlike a lot of people, I actually LIKE the rugged look. I don't need it (never drop my phone) but I like just knowing the protection is there and it has the extra plus of making it easier to hold. My only issue with this one is battery life which isn't overly bad but not great. I expect more from the S6. The non-removable battery isn't an issue but I do wish I could either use an SD card or they had higher capacity options. I also hope they continue the Active line as there were rumors around about that maybe going away. I can't think of any other smart phone made as solid/rugged except perhaps the higher end Nokia Lumias. Those are nice as well. And in case you're wondering... I HATE using cases.

thread.text:
I've had the Note 5 for a week now and thought I would post some things that I have noticed. 
WiFi strength on the same networks at home and work.. Much stronger reception and download speed with the Note 5 along with cell reception being better, not that it was terrible with the Active, but the Note 5 is better. 
The display.. The Note is clearer and brighter and again the Active wasn't bad in anyway. 
Battery life.. Right now after applying the great tweaks for the Active, I'm getting roughly the same for the Note 5 now, so I can only say if the Active Note does get made and keeps the same size battery it's going to be one killer phone in this regard. The battery management improvement is pretty great. 
No lag with the Note 5, and I didn't have any with my Active. 
The camera with the full pro settings and tweaks they did on the Note 5 is much better all around on dry land... 
Larger internal memory.. 64 gigs on the Note 5 vs 32 on the Active. 
Fingerprint scanner.. 
Louder speaker...and then the Active is as well but the Note is that much Louder 
S-pen. 
Now the negatives. 
No waterproofing No dust proofing No Activity buttons The glass back as opposed to the ruggedized case (IMHO) No IR blaster No MHL out on this
For myself I prefer holding the Active and carrying the Active. It's just a pure joy to not have to worry about it. The Note 5 naked is a slippery beast. 
That being said both are really is a fantastic phones and I don't think a person can go wrong with either one. My son is just loving the Active I had and that makes me really happy with giving it to him. When my wife gets ready to upgrade I'll get her one too since she's not a tech head like myself. If they get a Active Note out, I won't hesitate on getting one, but for now I will hang on to this one for a while and just be careful with it. 
There is always going to be trade offs choosing a smartphone, but in all honesty unless you need the extra storage and S-pen the Active is a awesome phone to own and doesn't cost as much.
Posted from my Galaxy Note 5

thread.text:
YES
Jed on GS6 active
Thanks again Tarah!

Overall, the S6 Active has been one of the best smartphones I've owned (Apple iPhone 3g, 4, 5, MotoX 2013, OnePlus One. Best screen ever, best camera ever. I've never dropped one of my previous phones (all have had cases). But within a week of owning this one, I dropped it while taking a photo... no damage except for a small scrape on this bad boy. I love that I don't have to have a case on this guy. Water resistance is awesome, My friend had an S5 that he washed under the sink after a 'dirty' meal and water resistance became a 'must have' for me. Battery life has been sufficient for me as it gets me through the day of pretty heavy use with near 5hr SOT and about 30% battery life remaining. Quick charging is awesome for when I just need a quick 'top off'. I find myself using my phone a lot more now that I don't worry about battery life. It is a pleasure just staring at that screen.
Now, the negatives. I replaced TouchWiz launch from day one and changed the theme to the free material one from the Samsung Theme store, however, CyanogenMod for the OnePlus just gave me sooo much more configurable options. The details from the tweaks are amazing. I miss double-tap to wake and some of the off screen gestures. There's just something about the Samsung OS that just keeps me from loving it. The physical buttons do take some getting used to. 
Now the possible game breaker for me. I noticed that when multi-tasking, unless I am switching between two very recent apps, that the OS recycles my apps much too quickly. They are on the multitasking window, but when I want to launch it, it has to start from the beginning. This is most noticeable on games since they take quite some time to load from scratch. So multitasking on the S6 (I think in all variants) is pretty poor. The worst thing is, with the Active variant, we'll probably be considered the last to get pushed updates since we are limited in population (and only on AT&T). This memory leak is documented across the internet and there may be hope in 5.1.1, but I don't have much faith that the Active will get that for quite some time. Anyone else notice this? I don't have a memory cleaner app, I've downloaded and tried to disable 'bloatware' with package disabler, but really, switching between open apps is much slower on this phone than on my previous phones. 
I love the phone, dislike the software, but wouldn't trade it in for any other flagship or upcoming flagship.

After all the help and advice I received here from you folks, I just ordered a new case, a package of tempered glass screen protectors and a Fast Charge Car cord for...
...wait for it...
...a Note 5! 
I spent about an hour at Best Buy yesterday afternoon with the Manager of their Cell Phone Dept and he owned a regular S6 and a new Note 5. He showed me all the good features of both the Note 5 and the S6 Active in the store - he actually likes the Active also but couldn't give up the pen, so he bought the Note 5.
My wife and I chatted back and forth about it on the way home and I looked back at how many little things I used the pen for. I couldn't say that I use it every day but I do use it enough to be used to having it there now. I used it twice last night and again today - I took some measurements on the roof of my RV and quickly jotted them down in S-Note. End of story! Thanks again for all the advice and help!

Have to agree...the S pen seems like a draw...but in actuality I used it very little when owning my notes 2 and 3...I simply can not place a high enough value on the ruggedness of the S6 active -- just fits me lol

I like my S6A quite a bit. Occasional lag here and there. I've found a quick restart every once and awhile helps. 
Great: 
Camera. 
Waterproof. 
Battery life and charging speed. 
General speed. 
Screen (image quality, autobrightness, outside/inside, accuracy/sensitivity). 
Mobile signal strength (better than iPhone 6, Xperia Z3C, and surprisingly, BlackBerry Q10 and Passport). 
In hand feel. 
Decent notification control. 
Decent customizabilty. 
Touchwiz way better than I remembered/expected. 
Eh: 
No Play edition. 
Occasional lag. 
Software updates (possibly, not expecting much here). 
Security (BlackBerry to Android user). 
32gb only. 
Aggressive RAM control (app and webpage reloads way more than Q10). 
Bluetooth volume control. 
No "keep screen on when I'm holding it" option like BlackBerry or Xperia (aside from the eyeball detecting thing). 
Little side panels get a weird coming loose feeling after a short time. 
No fingerprint unlock. 
Overall, I'm pretty happy with it. Kinda thinking about that Note 5 as it's the same overall size and that S-Pen looks really nifty. Is there really a Note 5 Active in the works?! 
As an aside (before I dash off to Google Note 5A) for all who say they don't need a case: I thought the same thing until I cracked my screen two weeks ago. Dropped it from about 4ft onto my concrete porch, landed face down. Didn't shatter, but it hairline cracked in two different directions starting from the far left side edge near the volume down button. Right next to the raised rail that's suppossed to protect the screen. 
I have a case on my replacement device now. 
~Sent via Turtle~

title: Disabled Samsung Print Service

thread.text:
I disabled Samsung print service on my Galaxy S6 Active (fully updated with latest ATT update). Disabling it caused a short freeze and then the screen went black, then it returned to normal. I also disabled many other apps and this did not happen with them. It would happen no matter how many times I renabled it and disabled it. I exchanged the phone incase it was a defect that might creep up in the future. 
The second one I got did this once after disabling Samsung Print Service. But not a second time. Did not feel like testing anymore.
I also checked a phone at the ATT store and it did not do this at all. It may be because my phone had the latest update or because the app was stopped at the time. Not sure.
But, since this happened with two phones, do you think I should worry about it? I would assume there is a good chance it could happen on a third one. It only happens with Samsung Print Service and does not appear to have any effect on any other aspect of the phone.
What do you think? Nothing to worry about?
I don't think I would worry about it too much. If you think it can cause problems, you can always re-enable the app, force stop it, and then never open it again.

title: How do I remove a notification from my homescreen?

thread.text: I have a Samsung and one day a notification on one of my apps popped up on my homescreen and won't let me exit the alert its for the app floating player can anyone help??
Welcome to the forums. Try longpressing the notification. From there, you should be able to disable notifications.

title: Recent Apps key stopped working

thread.text:
S6 Active / AT&T - I've had the device for about a month. Unable to specifically put my finger on 'when', but recently (within the last 10 days, maybe), my Recent Apps button stopped working. I don't THINK it was immediately after a recent update, but I could be wrong. It seemed intermittent for a day or two; sometimes worked and sometimes didn't - I suspected that the device was just lagging and didn't think much of it. Within a few days (and after at least one restart), it doesn't work at all.
No issues with the device. No drops (at all), haven't pushed any buttons too hard, etc. - no real reason to suspect a hardware problem. Restarted in Safe Mode - still doesn't work. Did a factory data reset and still doesn't work. Loaded All In One Gestures, attempting to have that app redirect button functionality - and had no luck. It's like the OS isn't detecting the button press at all.
Anyone else run into this? Running Android v5.0.2... (as AT&T hasn't pushed v5.1.1 out to the S6 Active yet...)

I suspect its just a bad button (Hardware)...it happens. What does it do if you hold the button down? Does it bring up the, "The Screen does not support split screen view,...." Screen?
You should notify samsung support and get a replacement device...."if they can't fix it of course." But it seems that's your only option, as you are outside of the normal return windows for carriers, I think.
Goto the bottom of the link's page below, and start a chat support. Mobile - Cell Phones - Samsung Support
Just a temporary solution while you work this out with Samsung may be:https://play.google.com/store/apps/d....navigationbar

Thanks for the replies, guys. I haven't chatted with Samsung themselves yet, but did do a support chat with AT&T. They came to the same conclusion... hardware. I know it happens, but it's pretty frustrating to drop $600 on a phone, absolutely BABY the thing, and this happens within 30 days. Gonna go to my AT&T store and see if they'll replace it with a new one...

title: Fastest way to MUTE a Locked GS6A?

thread.text:
I'm in and out of meetings, and I keep my phone locked.
On my previous Note II, after waking up the phone with the power button, if I pressed and held the power button, a window popped up that had Mute/Vibrate/Sound as three touchable items. Then I could mute it, and put the phone back to sleep with another press of the power button. Laborious (compared to the iPhone's physical switch), but that's all I had.
I tried the same with the GS6A and I get the window- But it only has Power/Airplane/Restart/Emergency Mode. No volume at all. 
How does someone quickly mute a locked phone?

Swipe down from the top on the lock screen, sound icon should be right there in the center of the notification (or whatever the proper name of it is) bar. From screen off, home or power button, swipe down, tap, silenced.

thread.text: Apparently, the app has gone live today. However, I don't see it when I search in Galaxy Apps or the Google Play store.

replies.text:

Who is your carrier?
S6 active is ATT. I'm guessing that until we get the 5.1.1 (whenever that is) it will be in the update
Not sure if it will have Samsung Pay. It seems Samsung has said no to a couple of people. I think the Active supports MST, but I can't find anything definitive concerning this though.
Not sure what MST is. Same phone as the GS6 other than the fingerprint scanner
That is Magnetic Secure Transmission. That is the thing that allows Android Pay to use something other than NFC and why any terminal that you swipe your card, will take Samsung Pay.
Thanks Kelly, now I can say I learned something new today

thread.text: When I click for Check Update on my phone, it says to wait about 9 hours which is when I'm guessing the update for samsung pay comes to the active.

This is technology that Samsung acquired, I'm assuming it is in the S6 Active, but if it isn't, it never will be. That is why phones before the S6 will never be able to use Samsung Pay but can us Android Pay, it is NFC. 
Also this is why Samsung Pay can be used around the world.

I emailed samsung on this yesterday and they replied that as of now the samsung pay app is not compatible with the s6 active. I tied to load the apk and framework apk onto my s6 active but it would not install.
